item.title: Accrington Stanley 3-3 Oxford United
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Lindfield 25
Beattie 80
Molyneux 90
3 - 3
Pittman 12
Constable 86
Raynes 90
The Crown Ground, Accrington
Attendance: 1,195

Oxford felt like they had won the game after two late comebacks, but the result hide a poor performance and defensive mishaps. The game was tinged with sadness at the news of the death of Mitchell Cole, but there was no minutes silence before the game. Instead OUFC fans gave a minutes applause in the 17th minute of the game. The U's took a relatively early lead. An ok ball down the flank put JP Pittman in a difficult position near the corner flag, but he turned his man beautifully, creating space along the byline. With no defenders blocking his path to goal Rachubka had to come out to face him, but the American took it past him and scored into the empty net. It was one of a few rare moments of class in an otherwise poor game.


JP Pittman's opening goal was a stunning run past the keeper.

Stanley drew level in the 25th minute as Oxford failed to deal with aball into the box. Amond should have scored but scuffed it badly. Instead it fell to Craig Lindfield who made no mistake. The contest was very close in the first half as Oxford's best work wa via Pittman and Rigg on the left of the pitch. Oxford finished with the better chances but none of the corners won ended with any decent shots on target. A massive blow for the season and for the game was when Pittman went down holding his shoulder. This sadly looks like it will be a sizeable absence but also weakened our attacking threat. The second disappointment was that Wilder chose to overlook Tyrone Marsh yet again, bringing on Davis to play left mid and moving Rigg up front where he could be less effective.

Damien Batt was introduced at half time and looked sharp and solid. He replaced Lee Cox as Andy Whing moved into a defensive midfield position for all of 2 minutes. As Whing overstretched for the ball in a tackle his knee went. I was worried about how long he would be out for until he got up and started walking. Then my earlier concern was right and he was down again, stretchered off and no doubt out for at least a month or two. So Adam Chapman was introduced and all hope of further tactical changes was gone with the third substitution. The lost of Cox, Pittman, and Whing really upset the drive of the team and we looked significantly poorer without them. There was little passion shown, it was the flatest of flat performances.

Former England international James Beattie had a free header but it was straight at Ryan Clarke. The Oxford stopper made another good save and Oxford were saved by some poor heading in front of goal. It was end to end yet disappointing. There were many goals to come in this second half and it was exciting for these moments but the whole event just wasn't exciting to watch from my point of view. Most of Oxford's impetus was on the left as Potter had a quiet game, but Constable and Rigg were determined to win this on their own. Michael Raynes provided danger from corners.

With 6 minutes left Beattie hit a speculative half volley from some way out and it sliced into the top corner. It was a superb hit if it was meant. Then Beano was put through by Chapman and hit it under Rachubka, 2-2. Davis could have won it but for Stanley's man of the match. Into injury time and Liam Davis lifted his foot high. He won the ball cleanly but the referee decided it was dangerous and it did look like quiet a silly challenge. The wall was placed nicely, but so was the free kick by Molyneux. Although it was curled nicely Ryan Clarke was massively at fault, he was just too central and didn't get across to an easily saveable strike. Let the wall cover one side and the keeper the other. Basics. 2-3. The unbelievable comeback was finished by the yellows as Leven crossed for Raynes to head in. A moment of huge excitement that didn't reflect the first 84 minutes very well. So a replay at the Kassam for a place in the third round. We celebrated this like a win, but a little reality check tells me that this was a subpar performance, and a draw against Accrington is a terrible result. Even game I think we need Wilder Out all that little bit more.

Booked: Winnard, Joyce. Sent off: None.

Booked: None. Sent off: None.

Man of the Match:

James Constable had some good chances, scoring the 2nd goal. He looked like he wanted to win this game while others looked less bothered

The opposition:

Stanley, vocal in persistence is not numbers, have had a poor run of form at home under Leam Richardson. They exploited some of Oxford's defensive weakness and scored two excellent goals at the end. There were about 16 Stanley fans who were giving United fans stick all throughout the second half and were the subject of some return chants themselves. They were schoolchildren all of about 10 years old.

Around the grounds:

Non-league sides Harrogate, Hastings, Lincoln, Mansfield and Luton all go into the hat for the third round, with the first four having to replay. The only upset was Burton beating League One Crewe.

item.title: Christmas Brewery update
item.description: More beers and wines for Christmas, plus a new bottling tool
item.author: Tino Race
item.content: I drove to Stonehelm on the way home from work, and have added another Christmas ale called Santa's Winter Warmer from Muntons, and a Belgian Abbey Ale using dark candy sugar to provide the classic almost burnt taste. I have made some more wines, peach, gooseberry, and blackberry. The best thing I bought was a new bottle capper. Hitting a metal tool with a hammer 40 times was getting tedious and tiring and I was breaking a bottle or two per batch. Also the capper I had didn't do a good job of sealing properly. I bought a tool called 'Emily' (don't know why its called it), which make the process of capping bottles much simpler and quicker.

item.title: Oxford United 2-1 Northampton Town
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Constable 15
Pittman 79
2 - 1
Platt 76
Kassam Stadium, Oxford
Attendance: 6,636

Oxford fans were left in a state of shock today: not only did our team win, but they played really well and we enjoyed watching the game. It's been a while hasn't it. Oxford have continued a recent habit of scoring early in games, when Alfie Potter created a bit of space to provide a low and well aimed cross to an unmarked James Constable with a very easy tap in. Another goal to add to his confidence. Northampton made areally good game of it and it was end to end stuff for most of the match. Rigg and Forster-Caskey both created great chances but hit the woodwork.


Jon-Paul Pittman scored for the first time in 10 months.

The pace of the game was good and a real postive for the U's was the improvement in midfield control. The return of Lee Cox was a major factor in this, plus an improvement in the game of Peter Leven who has been poor of late. Oxford lost the lead late on, but only for three minutes. A chip into the box was headed by Platt who was not marked well enough. The Cobblers were silenced when JP Pittman scored the winning goal. Whatever form Leven is in, he is usually always good for an assist, leading the way for this stat despite limited appearances this season. Another excellent long ball was picked up by the American striker who took a touch then rifled it inside the near post. To add to the travellers' misery veteran Clarke Carlisle was sent of for a cheap second yellow, succumbing to mistiming a challenge on Alfie Potter who was causing problems on the right wing after he dropped back then when Pittman replaced Forster-Caskey. All in all a top quality performance, but still only 18th, still 7 points off the playoffs.

Booked: Capaldi, Forster-Caskey. Sent off: None.
Northampton Team: Nicholls, Langmead, Tozer, East, Carlisle, Demontagnac (Platt 61 [1]), Harding, Hackett, Hornby, Akinfenwa, Robinson.
Booked: Langmead, Carlisle, Domntagnac, Robinson. Sent off: Carlisle.

Man of the Match:

Lee Cox seemed to bolster the midfield and we were strong in this area where we have found ourselve overrun in November.

The opposition:

Northampton arrived at the Kassam undefeated in November, and the back of three straight wins. This form lifted them to one point shy of the playoffs before the game. They provided a good opponent and made the game very entertaining. As time ticked away Northampton got more frustrated when Oxford were in possession and this showed in the high number of yellow cards picked up (one short of an FA fine). Tackles were rash and sometimes downright dirty. Akinfenwa held up the ball very effectively and I think most sides in the league would love to have him in their team, but he was ineffective when it came to shooting today.

Around the grounds:

Dagenham contributed to Fleetwood's recent poor form. Rotherham moved above Exeter with a win at St James's Park. Port Vales reduced the gap from Gillingham to two points. Bradford and Bristol Rovers shared a 3-3 draw despite being at opposite ends of the table, Bradford coming from behind an amazing three times.

item.title: Barnet 2-2 Oxford United
item.description: Oxford fail to beat the Football League's bottom club
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Hyde 5, 70  
2 - 2
Rigg 6
Whing 46
Underhill, Barnet
Attendance: 1,626

Oxford United threw away a lead at Underhill tonight to extend a season of underperforamance and failure to meet expectations. It was a rainy evening in North London but Oxford fans numbered 500 of the 1626 crowd. The match had a lively opening 20 minutes with boths sides having the chances they should have scored, more so Barnet. After only 4 minutes a corner was conceded by United and the inevitable happened. Once a again a yellow shirt failed to win a header in either box and Jake Hyde got under the ball. His header looped over Ryan Clarke into the far corner. Wilder recently deflected criticism of this aspect of our performances (with a typically anti-fans comment), his team does practice corners in training. Of this I have no doubt. Whether the coaching staff have any good ideas on ways to defend wide balls, I have severe doubts.

Less than a minute later the visitors were celebrating as Oxford's high pressure lead to Constable knocking down for Rigg in the penalty area who fired home to equalise. Oxford continued to have the better of the game and look comfortable, except for when Barnet countered. Too many crosses were allowed, but only poor finishing and bad luck kept the score at 1-1.

The second half had the perfect start as the U's won a free kick which was crossed in by Peter Leven. Andy Whing thundered the header into the goal, off the underside of the crossbar. At 2-1 this should have been game over as Barnet looked capable of giving away more goals. But now the game began to slip from Oxford's control. Barnet claimed more possession for themselves, Kamdjo dominating the middle, while Chapman and certainly Leven began to look absent. Heslop was replaced on the hour mark by JP Pittman, with Alfie Potter dropping back from support striker to right wing in a 4-4-2. This change seemed to take us further out of the game as Heslop was playing reasonably well. Forster-Caskey has the popularity of a player who had just slept with the manager's wife. He was overlooked as our midfield was being overrun. Tyrone Marsh continues to warm the bench. He needs to come on in a game we're winning to provide an extra problem for the opponent's defence to think about.

All we want is a team of Andy Whings. Especially when he can scored headers like the one today.

The three points were surrendered quite early as Hyde scored from another cross which we failed to defend. This gave Oxford 20 mintues plus to get the right result, but the close was disappointing. A rare indirect free kick in the box was won when the Barnet goalkeeper had to make a top corner save from a back pass. The resulting shot was easily blocked by a large wall of amber and black. Only right at the end did we ask a suitable question of Barnet as Johnny Mullins' header hit the right post, bounced along the goal line, hit the left post, then bounced out. If it had gone in it would not have been a fair reflection of the game. A draw was about right, which is sad given that one team was challenging near the playoffs last season, while Barnet continue to be rock bottom of England's 92 clubs.

Barnet Team: Stack, Fuller, Brown, Kamdjo, Stephens, Pearce, Byrne, Yiadom, Nurse, Holmes (Lee 88), Hyde.
Booked: Kamdjo, Brown. Sent off: None.
Oxford Team: Clarke, Whing, Mullins, Wright, Capaldi, Rigg, Chapman, Leven, Heslop (Pittman 60), Constable, Potter.
Booked: Constable, Whing. Sent off: None.

Man of the Match:

In what turned out to be his last match for the club, Johnny Mullins was on of only two players truely in the game. He came so close to getting the winning goal with his last touch in a yellow shirt. He will be sorely missed.

The opposition:

Barnet try to play a good brand of football under their suspended player coach Edgar Davids. They are rooted to the bottom of League Two and we failed to show why they deserve to be here.

On Tour: Underhill

I nearly didn't go to Underhill tonight based on recent performances, results, and the fact it was a Tuesday night. I'm glad I made the effort though as this was my last chance to go to this ground before the Bees move into a new Community Stadium next season. It's a 'proper ground', one where the stands have been built in sections with no thought whatsoever to the overall design. A ground where you can watch the game from your back bedroom if you house is in the right place. A ground where they don't take the mick when charging you for a hot chocolate or burger. It's friendly too.

See the panorama

Around the grounds:

Wimbledon and Bristol Rovers were smashed by Southend and Port Vale respectively, both by four goals. Wymcombe's win at a depleted Rotheram helped force the hand of Steve Evans in recalling Mullins. Northampton's win sees them one point below the playoff coming into Saturday match at the Kassam.

item.title: Walking in Snowdonia
item.description: Staff away weekend at the Emily Kelly Hut, November 2012
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
The penultimate weekend in November was the last opportunity to have a walking holiday this year. I went as part of the Lord Williams's School staff outdoors trip. We stayed at the Emily Kelly Hut, right in the middle of Snowdonia, south of Capel Curig. The hut sits at the bottom of a deep valley (Nant Gwynant) next to a hydroelectric power station, at the end of a stony track. It is a perfect place for exploring Snowdon and the Glyders. The traffic from Thame to Wales was not to bad and we dined at the Berwyn Arms, in Glyndyfrdwy, a village the name of which I'm grateful to be typing not pronouncing.


A walk up the Glyders. Though the style on the right seems a bit pointless.

On Saturday morning we set off by foot from the hut, walking up the valley north to the cafe at Pen-y-Pass, where we stopped for a coffee. It was a very warm morning for November in the sunshine. We then crossed the road and proceeded to climb up Glyder Fawr, then Glyder Fach, then turning south once near Tryfan to the junction of the A4086 and A498. Here we were expecting the Pen Y Gwryd hotel to be open for a pint, but it had scaffolding and was shut. It was not clear when or if it would reopen. So we had to continue to walk back to the hut, down a track. In the evening we drove to the Tyn-Y-Coed pub in Capel Curig, a place I have been before. They have a nice range of sausages with mash and it was very busy, but we only had to wait half an hour for food. The selection of ales was excellent.

The next morning we got up with confidence and an ambition to climb Tryfan, but were held back by the large numbers of sausages and bacon that needed cooking, then eating. So with limited daylight we drove north to start a walk up Tal-y-Fan near Conwy, a trip of about 150 minutes.

item.title: CS50x Week 3: Searching and sorting algorithms
item.description: How to program algorithms to sort data in an array and search arrays
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
This week's theme was how to search data for information, and how to do it as quickly as possible. If you were to search a phone book for a person, you would not start at A, then look through each name in turn until you came upon the person you wanted, especially if they were called Zlatan Zamalovic. This would be a 'linear search' and can be sometimes useful but not when an array is thousands or millions of data long. In its place you would use a binary search, picking a point in the middle, and seeing which side of the middle the required term was in. By discarding the unnecessary half, the problem is halved each step. The number of steps to solve the problem follows log (n) where n = the size of the problem. This only works where the data is already sorted, like a phone book

So we now need to know how to sort arrays. One option would be a Bubble sort where you pass along the array, comparing two values and if necessary swapping them. When you reach the end of the array you make another pass of the data, again swapping pairs where needed. The largest values bubble up to the top of the array. When you make a pass and make no swaps you know the problem is solved and you can stop. In a worst case scenario this could involved n2 steps. Another type called selection sort would involve passing along the array, keeping note of the lowest value, then swapping this to the start of the array, then passing again until you have done n passes. This will also take n2 steps to complete. By far the best option for large data sets (greater than 50) is merge sort, which breaks down an array of size n to n arrays of size 1. By comparing pairs of these smaller arrays, they can quickly be sorted into arrays of size 2. Then pairs of these arrays are rearranged to make larger arrays until the prolem is complete. This has the advantage of taking only n * log (n) steps to solve. One of the key messages was that there is always a trade off, whether it is increasing memory usage to reduce processing time, or increasing loading time to reduce later processing time. There is even the consideration to make of whether it is worth spending an extra hour or so improving the code if it only saves a second each time the program is run.

As part of PSET3 I started by making a binary search algorithm for presorted data, then sorting programs of the Bubble, Selection, and Insertion variety. The merge sort is more tricky and requires a lot more code to achieve. I then had to edit a program which makes the game 'Scrmable', adding functions to check if an entered word can be made using a random grid of letters and is in the dictionary. The grid function prints the grid of letters and is easy, the scramble function is easy, you just have to do some simple maths using a temporary array to rotate the grid. The harder function is the one which lookups up the entered word in the dictionary file and requires considerably more lines of code.

item.title: Brewing
item.description: Beers and wines for Christmas
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Recently I've been without any home brew beers so I worked extra hard on a Sunday without much else to do to rectify this. In kegs I have a Stout and a lighter ale called Sundown (new from Woodforde's). Not very festive, but it was new so I was curious to try it. I have also bottled two ales: one is Christmas Ale called Donner and Blitzed from Milestone, the other a copper brew from a cheaper range of kits. All of these should be ready by the time I put up the Christmas tree in two weeks.

In vinting news I bottled four wines as well. Sauvignon Blanc and Cabernet Sauvignon from the California Connoisseur range, and an Apple and Gooseberry kit from the Young's fruit wine selection. Only an hour after it was bottled we drank one of the Gooseberry bottles and it was excellent; deliciously crisp and fresh.

A new tool in the armoury is alcotec's topup spirit range. For £2.99 you get a screw top bottle, which contains a small amount of liquid which just needs topping up with plain spirit (i.e. vodka). Bailey's and Jagermeister have now been added to the drinks cupboard.

item.title: Oxford United 0-0 Torquay United
item.description: Not much to say about this one, a better performance but still little progress up the league and nothing to inspire the missing fans to return.
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
0 - 0

Kassam Stadium, Oxford
Attendance: 5,773

To say Oxford United played poorly would be unfair, but it is clear that the turn around we have been promised with a fully fit squad is not transpiring. It was definitely an improvement on Tuesday night, and some good chances were created (though not finished). I can't say I heard the boos that were supposed to have eminated from certain sections of the ground, but I suspect they were more out of frustration at the long term situation the club is in rather than being endemic of a poor performance on the day. I was left with mixed feelings when the referee gave one last blast on his whistle. Relief that we hadn't lost to a club who challenge at the right end of the table. Pleased by some of the individual performances, annoyed with those who we know can deliver but aren't turning up at the moment. Frustration. Deep, deep frustration at the lack of a forward drive.

Tom Craddock was nominated for the league two player of the month. It was a shame that he had to go off at half time (injury, what else at this club?). James Constable was voted Oxford Player of the Month. He has provided vital assists and his alround game has been top notch. Finishing? Just don't ask him to score a goal. He had a range of chances, mainly where he played the offside trap well from long balls, but fluffed his lines in front of the keeper. While on the subject of awards I heard Chris Wilder was nominated for October manager of the month as well. At the moment there are fans who wouldn't even give him Oxford manager of the the month.


Simon Heslop had one of his better games, despite being played out of position.

Simon Heslop was played out of position on the right as Alfie Potter continues to recover from a hamstring niggle. Wilder said in interview he didn't want to change the system as it had been working. Isn't the golden rule of management to choose the best system for the players you have, not the other way around? While often lambasted, Heslop put in a good showing. The same cannot be said for Peter Leven, currently looking out of his depth in League Two. We know he's better than this. Is it lack of fitness? Lack of ambition and direction? Meanwhile we have Forster-Caskey warming the bench. I can understand that he may well not stay so the side must be shaped in the long term, but if Leven's not performing you have to go wit the best set of 11 on any one day.

The final say was had by Martin Rice, Torquay's goalkeeper. Adam Chapman hit the ball low and well. How Rice got down quick enough to not only stop a certain goal, but hold on to it is a mystery. But it was a quality save that earned Torquay a point which no one can grumble with.

Oxford Team: Clarke, Wright, Whing, Mullins, Heslop (Chapman 81), Rigg, Cox, Leven, Davis, Constable, Craddock (Pittman 46).
Booked: Cox. Sent off: None.
Torquay Team: Rice, Oastler, Nicholson, Downes, Saah, Lathrope (Yeoman 74), Mansell, Bodin, Easton, Craig, Jarvis (Thompson 68).
Booked: None. Sent off: None.

Man of the Match:

I think all Oxford fans were delighted to see Johnny Mullins return to the starting lineup. He was very solid at the back and we never really looked like conceded. Corners and crosses were defended properly and it is essentially we can extend his loan deal when it expires soon.

The opposition:

Initially Torquay came to play football, but they looked a shadow of their former selves from last season when they challenged for the playoffs. As the game wore on and Oxford had the better chances, they became more content to sit back and see out the game with a point. Some timewasting was done, but the extra five minutes at the end only prolonged the misery of the event for both sets of fans.

Around the grounds:

Dagenham's 5-0 win over Steve Evan's Rotherham was the biggest shock of the day. They have now moved up to mid-table. Gillingham look unbeatable, rescuing a point at Plymouth. Wimbledon and Bristol Rovers will be pleased wit their wins which leave Barnet and Aldershot in even more danger of dropping out of the Football League.

item.title: CS50x Week 2: Crytopgraphy
item.description: Arrays, loops, and dealing with strings in C
item.author: Tino Race
item.content: In week 2 of CS50x I was set a challenge to make an algorithm which encrypted data. This used the principle of ASCII math, where each ASCII character is represented by a number and this number can be changed using a key. In the Caeser key, all letters are changed by a fixed amount, e.g. if the key if 'g', then all characters are shifted up by 7, with letter higher than Z looping back to A. The Vigenere key requires the user to enter a key word, then each letter in the text is shifted depending where in the key you are, e.g. is the key is 'dog', then the first letter is shifted by 4, the 2nd by 15, the third by 7, then the fourth is shifted by 4 again as we return to the first character in the key. The concept of loops and arrays was introduced too, as C is incapable of recognising strings, so a string in C is really an array of characters over which you must iterate to do somthing with that string.

item.title: Greenwich Museums
item.description: National Maritime Museum, Queen's House, and the Royal Observatory
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Our final stop on our tour of South London was to the free museum at Greenwich. They are the National Maritime Museum, Queen's House, and the Royal Observatory and form part of the Royal Museums, Greenwich. The fourth member of this group is the Cutty Sark which you can see clearly but there is a charge to tour it. I drove into Greenwich but there is very limited free parking and it seemed very expensive for four hours, so we headed away from the river and parked for free in Deptford, a 5 minute walk from the Deptfor DLR stop. It was two stations along to Cutty Sark station. Greenwich has lots of nice restaurants, markets and shops, and we ate at Café Rouge using the Taste Card.


One of the displays at the Maritime Museum is of ship's figureheads.

The closest free museum from the town centre is the National Maritime Museum, covering different types of boats, the roles of sea-going vessels in the colonisation of the Americas and opening of trade routes, and paintings and a cartoons of major naval event through history. Further on is Queen's House which is a portrait gallery on several levels and a convoluted route through to access all the different levels. From here you can go up the hill (5-10 minutes and its quite steep) to get to the Royal Observatory. There is a free visitors' centre which interactive videos, games, and photographs. In the gift shop I found an awesome Nuclear Physics tie which I now own. You can pay to see the Greenwich Meridian of GMT fame, and a selection of telescopes.

item.title: Crystal Palace Park
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Crystal Palace park is an excellent park in South London. The park is home to a National Sports Centre, and the site of the former Crystal Palace exhibition hall which was destroyed by fire in 1936. As you enter from the south side of the park the first thing you encounter is the dinosaur lake. There are a range of model dinosaurs near the water and on the island in he lake. Around the circumference are information boards and and an audio trail offering more information about the dinosaurs at each station. There is a farm which is free to enter but has limited opening times so check the website for this. The maze claims to be one of the largest in the country and is challenging. Rovers deserved to take the lead when Etuhu headed against the bar from a Pedersen corner. Murray won a penalty which he promptly score, but he was denied his hatrick after Robinson saved a second penalty. There was little sign of a comeback from 0-2 down. item.title: The 39 Steps
item.description: Pub, dinner, and the theatre: a proper grown up's evening
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
The 39 Steps is a long-running, famous play in London's West End. Originally the plan had been to go to Rock of Ages or We Will Rock You, but some very cheap tickets at £12 each were available, so we went to this adaptation of an Alfred Hitchcock film, itself based on an earlier book. We had no idea what it would be about. The basic premise is that a normal man living in London gets himself caught up in a spy plot about the mysterious '39 Steps' and is chased to Scotland under suspicion of murder.

The unique thing about this play is that there are only four cast members: the lead male, a female who plays all of the women, and two other people who play all of the remaining characters. This can either be as quick change back stage, or even costume change in the middle of sentences! The play doesn't take itself seriously at all, in fact it makes light of itself throughout and the script is peppered with puns relating to Hitchcock's other films. The play is hilarious and well acted. The £12 seat were restricted view, so there was a post in view and you are a fair way back but for the price I didn't feel this detracted enough to warrant paying a higher value.

Before the theatre we dined at Franco's, a nice Italian restaurant using the Taste Card (even on a Friday night), and had a drink in the Montagu Pyke (Wetherspoons) and then at The Tom Cribb (a Shepherd Neame) pub.

item.title: Mathematics in Science
item.description: A day of CPD at Rutherford Appleton Laboratory to investigate ways of teaching Maths in Science lessons
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
I spent a Wednesday on a teacher training course at the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory (only the visitors' room, we did not get the see the actual lab unfortunately). We started by discussing what sorts of things students struggle with. We identified units as being a problem, such as the confusion in Chemistry with are confusing e.g. dm3 and litres, how ml and cm3 are unintuitively the same. With A-level it is good to show that units balance in equations.

AS expected graphs were discussed. Showing a well thought out graph can promote good discussion and are very good for Y12 classes. So we dissected two graphs. For a simple journey to school, writing a description of a distance-time graph is much better for checking understand than just doing a calculation. Gradients are not always obvious so using numbers on the scale is important for interpreting speed. If the graph is a displacement-time graph it adds a higher level of understanding. The important thing is that you look for a story that is consistent with the facts. We then looked at a graph where two objects crossed. When describing the graph we realised that uniform, constant, steady all mean the same so why have 3 words? Care must be taken when taking about acceleration: the units of m/s/s or m/s2 can be confusing and it is important to avoid talking about 'fast' acceleration. For this type of graph 'Where are they travelling at the same same speed' is a clever question to catch out people. It is of course the place of same gradient not where the lines cross. Now we have to take the tangent to discover the instantaneous speed. Another concept to introduce. Our final discussion point was two F1 cars chasing each other. We were asked 'Where is the bend?': It's where the speed of the cars is lowest but you would also expect the answer to have a a range from entry to exit. Don't use the words 'starts at 0', often it's the recording that starts then. Looking at the change in the distance travelled can give a clue as to the acceleration. In this graph the average speeds seemed to decrease with a constant deceleration. The F1 question would make a good Gifted and Talented challenge. Remember that F1 distances are actually given in times. In GCSE Maths students are taught vector transformations of graphs and that's what this is. One of the biggest challenges of graphs is the scale, so I think lots of practice on this is needed at KS3.

In session 2 we looked at 'Improving learning in mathematics', a series of folders of resources. The aim of it is to improve practical teaching in maths and uses things like card sorts. Below are some of my random notes from the session:

What is area? Not using formulae, it's about covering a surface (amount of surface). Comes up in pressure and surface area to volume ratio Calculate the area taken up by 1 million pound coins. At 22.5mm diameter the area is 22.5x22.5 m or 506m2. It's worth spending time seeing what a million looks like (e.g. Printing off an A1 sheet with a million dots on.
Data - Can show some data and manipulate the outcome in two different ways for two different groups. Will promote independent thinking.

Prime numbers - Laying out coins as you count them shows factors, squares. Prime numbers don't rectangulate.

Fractions - Issues when dividing by numbers less than 1, confusion occurs when you end up with a larger answer.
Misconception is that dividing by half is the same as sharing between two people.

Percentages - Have a volume of water in a beaker to represent input energy. Then share out between two beakers to represent heat energy and light energy for a light bulb. Use for teaching Sankey diagrams use coloured water to help show it up.
In chemistry using a diagram of a molecule can help visualise percentage compositions.

Pythagoras - Can check football pitches are squared by using a chain 12 long that forms a 3,4,5 triangle.

Common misconceptions
Lifting a rope 1.6m off ground always increases circumference by 10m
10km at 10kmph then 10km at 20kmph is not 15kmph. Don't take averages of averages!

Charles' Law School Science Review June 2010 measure a balloon expansion better than standard apparatus just put balloon in the freezer can get absolute zero.

Get PhET downloaded onto school network

The Next Step

As I teach each topic at KS3 this year, I will look at how much Maths I can shoehorn into lessons. I will be doing this with Y7 and Y8. I will then evaluate the success of the various approaches and look to add them to the Schemes of work next year.

item.title: Oxford United 5-0 Accrington Stanley
item.description: A marvellous response to last Monday's drubbing with a comprehensive home victory.

item.content:

Potter 78
5 - 0

Kassam Stadium, Oxford
Attendance: 5,403

Bouyed by the return of some key players, Oxford United thumped Accrington Stanley, with the bulk of the goals coming from an on-form Tom Craddock. The Yellows started brightly, dominating possession and chances. The first goal came when the ball fell to Craddock after a series of attempts, his shot not being held by the keeper Dunbavin and finding the back of the net. His second came eleven minutes later when he was the quickest on a ball in the penalty area. Stanley players got back to defend, so Craddock took the ball out wide for the cross, but seeing no challenge he took it back towards goal and finished low into the bottom left-hand corner. The early two goal cushion was not something Accy could ever come back from which really help an Oxford team low in confidence play their natural game and relax into the occasion. Craddock completed his first half hatrick, again thanks to good Oxford pressure and poor Stanley defending. He was on hand to blast the ball high into the middle of the net. The first half was a superb 45 minutes for the U's. The midfield pairing of Cox and Forster-Caskey were really up for it, winning tackles and keeping the ball moving. Potter and Rigg provided excellent width, and the 4-4-2 formation suited the players on the park today.

After a great first half, the second half started in a disappointing fashion, with an understandably lower tempo, Stanley having time on the ball and winning loose balls more frequently. Eventually Oxford got going again, finding their best option being Sean Rigg. With the game won it was the perfect opportunity to bring on Peter Leven who replaced Forster-Caskey. His sublime touch and extraordinary vision created some good chances. A fit Leven will be key to turning the season around. More corners and chances followed, and the fourth for Oxford and Craddock came after good work from Constable. He out ran the defender to carry the ball into the box, then selflessly puled it back for Craddock place it simply into the goal. Oxford's final goal was created by Peter Leven's magical cross, Alfie Potter taking advantage of the left back's missed clearance hitting it under the keeper. It could have been more but Dunbavin was actually one of the best players on the pitch, saving from an Andy Whing header directed at the top corner.


Andy Whing returned to the team after long-term injury and was superb.

item.title: Oxford City 5-0 Workington
item.description: My first view of a Conference North match and I liked it.
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Ballard 27
Shariff 47
Cook 79
Basham 82,87
5 - 0

Court Place Farm, Oxford

Today I put on my Blackburn Rovers scarf and went down to Court Place Farm, where the blue and white colours worked well at Oxford City's home game against Workington. I was expecting good things as City have made a good start to their debut in their highest ever position in the football pyramid. Entrance was £11, though there were additional entrance offers being run in celebration of Non-League Day, a day aimed at getting Premiership and Championship fans along to their non-league alternatives over the international weekend. I was able to go as Oxford United's match was moved to Monday to be shown on Sky Sports.


Court Place Farm, Oxford.

Workington, a former league club but before my time, were the prettier passing team and played the better football. They were unable to really create any chances while City were clinical and efficient going forward. Workington started brightly with an early corner, but City had the better chances. Declan Benjamin on the overlap down the right wing and put in a fantastic cross for ex-Oxford United striker Jamie Cook but he handled the ball. He then set up another, beating two players with pace and trickery, but Darren Pond was guilty of a band miss, blasting over on the volley when a header seemed the better option. Captain Andy Ballard was impressive in the first half and was at the centre of many of City's best opportunities. His long, arrow-like throw-in earned a corner, which he then headed on target but was cleared off the line.

Workington had a good break against the Oxford City pressure and looked like they would create something but Jacob Walcott tracked back superbly, winning the ball before putting Cook through on goal. The goalie made the angle narrow and Cook's shot was inches wide. Another Ballard throw won another corner taken by left-back Paul Stonehouse. He spotted the run of right-back Jack Mills who was tracked too lazily by Workington's Jake Simpson. Mills passed it into the six yard box where Ballard picked up the ball, turned, and hit straight into the roof of the net. A deserved 1-0 leadgoing into the break. It could have been more when Ballard's cross found summer-signing Nabil Shariff who could only head wide. The skipper was finished, again pipcking out Shariff who in turn knocked on to Banjamin who thundered a half-volled just over the bar.


Oxford City in action against Workington.

Two minutes into the second half the game was dead and buried as Shariff capitalised on a mistake by the keeper to tap in. Apparantly. I was in the queue for a sausage bap and didn't see it. Benjamin, who had caused problems on the right, went off injured. Workington had a good chance from a free kick hit over the wall but Warren Carter was positioned well to save. Then enter Steve Basham, anothe ex-OUFC striker, and a class apart. A good ball up to him gave him a shot at goal which was only parried. Jamie Cook was fastest, but he was patient, waited for the keeper to commit to the ground, before dinking it over him. Very classy goal. It was not long before 3-0 turned into 4-0 as Stonehouse crossed for Basham to flick it past the oncoming goalkeeper. Cook's fine game came to an end when replaced by Felipe Barcelos. The talented Brazilian forward came close, volleying just over from the edge of the penalty area. Basham then crowned a fine cameo performance to make it 5-0 when he was found unmarked, blasting it into the net.

An excellent win for the home team, the result embarrased a far from poor Workington. This was City's 7th win out of their first twelve games and while they will struggle to catch the likes of Brackley and Chester who may well walk this league, they are putting themselves in a great position to achieve a play-off spot.

item.title: Kayaking the Thames from Redbridge to Abingdon (River
item.description: An easy route made quiet by no river traffic
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
The route I took today started near Redbridge park and ride, on Oxford's Southern bypass, starting on Weir's Mill Stream, joining Hinksey Stream, then the River Thames at the Kennington Railway Bridge. The only lock on route was the Sandford Lock, which we portaged via the weir branch. Our end point was Abingdon at the Abbey Meadows car park. You can view the MapMyRun route page, or see a 3D fly through below.

The first thing to do was drop the kayak at the put in. We pulled over on Abingdon Road by the Redbridge Park and Ride to do this. I took the kayak to a field. The gate was locked but no one was around so it was easy to get to. Jo drove the car and left it at the Abbey Meadows car park in Abingdon which is free on a Sunday. She then got the bus (X13, X3, X2, or 35 will all do) to Redbridge and walked to meet me in the field. A man approached me as I was waited and he didn't want to encourage launching here as it was private fishing land. He explained that normally there are ponies in the field, boats moored, and fishermen fishing here, but it was quiet because thje river was so high. He was nice enough and was ok for me to launch on this occasion but on another time this is not a recommended place to put in.

I had kayaked up Weirs Mill Stream on my last kayaking trip, but this time we headed downstream away from Oxford. Upstream takes you to the Thames with access to Iffley, but heading south it is quicker to go downstream to meet with Hinksey Stream just after the Ring Road. This then connects to the River Thames south of Iffley Lock at a railway bridge. The water level was high and after returning home I found that the Environment Agency website listed this part (and most parts) as CAUTION STRONG STREAM in a red background. The key said this: 'We advise users of all boats not to navigate because the strong flows make it difficult and dangerous.' The inflatable (and unsinkable) Colorado Sevylor is very stable and I had no problem being out on the river, perhaps a more traditional kayak might be at more risk. With these warnings in place there was no other rivers traffic which was great not having to get out of the way of powered boats.

The only lock was Sandford lock. The left fork going downstream takes you to the lock, the right to the weir, which was thunderous with the water level. We got out on the right bank of the right fork, well before the weir, and found a narrow but walked path. We portages as far as the weir, then turned to the right down the bank to the lower level of the river. Here it is quiet, calm and surrounded by trees, a very easy put in as long as the vegetation is not too overgrown.

The rest of the journey was straight forward down to Abingdon Lock. The lock is connected by a footpath over the lock and weir to Abbey Meadows, a large park in Abingdon. While we've walked around here a lot in the past we decided to get out at the lock and walk it over the narrow weir bridge. We couldn't quite remember whether the stream running into the park was before or after the weir and didn't want to risk it in the strong stream. There was not too much pedestrian traffic to impede us but on a sunny day you will find a lot of people coming in the opposite direction. Once over the weir bridge we were able to put in at the stream. If the river is calm and you are a competent kayaker you can just paddle straight from the Thames into the stream as long as you keep well over to the right bank away from the weir. We finished journey on this calm backwater leading right upto the site of the former abbey and a short walk from the car park. There were only ducks here as it was October, but I would not do this earlier in the year as it is a swan nesting area, and there is not really anywhere to get away from them. If it is springtime, just walk!

item.title: Oxford United 0-0 Gillingham
item.description: 0-0 doesn't do justice to this game, a good Oxford performance, just not enough up front.
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
0 - 0

Kassam Stadium, Oxford
Attendance: 6,690

The result doesn't quite explain the performance or the match. Gillingham were by far the more dominant team, but a plucky Oxford pulled off their first clean sheet since Swindon against the league leaders to hold on for a deserved point. Gillingham had the lion's share of possession and created a decent number of chances, but a makeshift defence did well. When Batt went off injured the back four of Boateng, Mullins, Wright, and O'Brien had not played together before. Smalley also was injured in the first half. The rate of at least two injuries per match is becoming a joke and there is something desperately wrong to be causing this - it can't simply be 'luck'. It forced Wilder's hand as ideally Constable would have come on sooner, but with two subs already made it had to be left late. There is certainly a problem between Wilder and Constable as he was second choice off the bench to Craddock at half time.

There were good performances from Heslop after starting the season poorly, and Rigg was causing problems again down the left. Oxford finished the game very strongly putting the Gills on the back foot, but only five shots, none of which were on target shows how light weight we are up front at the moment. Defensively this was a very solid and positive match but there is definitely a issue in chance creation and conversion as a result of the way we play.


Simon Heslop is finding his previous form and earning himself a place in the side.
Oxford Team: Clarke, Batt (Boateng 42), Wright, O'Brien, Mullins, Chapman, Heslop, Rigg, Forster-Caskey, Smalley (Craddock 46), Potter (Constable 82).
Booked: None. Sent off: None.

Booked: Findley, Kedwell. Sent off: None.

Man of the Match:

In any other game the obvious choice would have been new boy Johnny Mullins who offered fantastic protection and a dominate presence in the back four. But everyone's MOM today was Ryan Clarke who pulled off some Gordon Bank's like saves to keep Oxford in the game. The saves were genuinely world class.

The opposition:

I thought Oxford fans who suggested that they didn't know how Gillingham could be top of the league were not giving a fair analysis. Gillingham played as well as Exeter did, the only difference was that Oxford played well in this game unlike in the Exeter match. This was the Gills' first non-win away from home and only the 3rd match in which they've dropped points. It will be interesting to see next Monday's game against Port Vale to compare these two promotion chaising teams. I fully expect Gillingham will be still up there in May.

Around the grounds:

At the bottom end, Bristol Rovers, Wycombe, Wimbledon, and Dag and Red had massive wins, leaving Barnet trailing on 3pts in 11 games. Aldershot are now in 23rd place losing at home to Chesterfield. Port Vale caught up on the Gills while newboys Fleetwood occupy the 3rd automatic promotion place. Oxford are 5 points off the play offs and 5 points off the relegation zone.

item.title: Nottingham Forest 0-0 Blackburn Rovers
item.description: Another quiet defensive away performance and another draw
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
0 - 0

City Ground, Nottingham
Attendance: 18,748
Paul Robinson was Rovers' busiest player as Forest created chance after chance.

My second Rovers away game in a row saw no improvement in the performance in performance and less attack and more defence. I might think I am a bad omen. A more sensible conclusion would be that Eric Black isn't going to get this team playing well and we are desperately in need of a manager to come in and put things right. Like in the Charlton match, Rovers started strongly, then sat deeper and deeper, inviting Forest forward. Forest had 17 chances to Rovers 5 which is a poor stat for a Blue fan. The most telling stat of the game was this though: each side only had 1 shot on target. And it was this that really let Rovers off the hook. Forest failed to convert the simplest of chances, while Rovers failed to create any.

The away end had a great atmosphere with fans in fine form. Perhaps it was the defensive 5-3-2 formation that prevented Rovers from playing well. Luckily the defense which usually lets in at least one goal a game kept a clean sheet, a rarity since the loss of Big Sam, and it was well timed. Black was too slow to make the changes in the second half and by the time he did it was just a case of hanging on for the point. We missed Etuhu in midfield who was out with flu. Hopefully Rovers can play better at the weekened against Wolves in front of a packed Ewood.

Danny Murphy's performance once again drew criticism from the fans. I just cannot see what he brings to the team.
Nottingham Forest Team: Camp, Harding, Collins, Halford, Ayala, Gillett, Cohen, McGugan (Jenas 72), Reid (Coppinger 85), Lansbury (Majewski 63), Sharp.
Booked: None. Sent off: None.
Blackburn Team: Robinson, Orr, Martin Olsson, Givet, Dann, G Hanley, Lowe, Formica, Murphy, Rhodes (Dunn 86), Nuno Gomes (Kazim-Richards 63).
Booked: None. Sent off: None.

Man of the Match:

Although Paul Robinson made some good saves, Grant Hanley was also kept very busy, but he generally dealt very well with ball crossed into the box and made solid defensive headers all night.

The opposition:

Forest weren't expecting this to be such an easy game for them, but struggled to take the myriad of chances presented to them and that they created. This shows how difficult it is when you only have one fit striker. Defensively they seemed solid, keeping Gomes, and Rhodes especially, very quiet all game. If they can start taking their chances they will move up to the right end of the table after a difficult season last year, with effectively a brand new team still waiting to gell properly.

On Tour: City Ground, Nottingham

Nottingham from Oxfordshire is a long journey on a Wednesday night, but I made it anyway. Even though Forest wanted to move to a new ground if the World Cup came to Nottingham, the City Ground is still a great stadium, worthy of the Premiership. Forest fans were very quiet, only really getting going towards the end of the evening. The whole atmosphere outside the ground was very friendly and there is a lot of stall geared up for the football. What a pleasure it is to have a stadium within reasonable walking distance of a city centre in the modern era.

Around the grounds:

Middlesbrough and Derby's 2-2 draw was the only other game tonight, as other clubs played in Tuesday. Cardiff's win over Birmigham keeps them top, a point ahead of Leicester and another from Brighton who slip to third. Blackpool came from behind to beat Hull. Crystal Palace's 2-1 defeat of Wolves sees them climb to 7th, a shock position after last season's misery.

item.title: Oxford United 3-2 Wimbledon
item.description: A feeling of relief for the players and fans as Oxford record a timely win in an entertaining game.
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Forster-Caskey 9
Smalley 55
Potter 81
3 - 2
Harrison 20
Fenlon 36
Kassam Stadium, Oxford
Attendance: 5,206

In a Tuesday night match between two of the leakiest defences in the league, the 3-2 win to Oxford says it all. The fact that both teams failed to hold onto a lead reflects the situation they are in. Both teams even had a goalkeeper called Brown who didn't play very well. The parallels were broken though by the quality of finishing in easy situation, on which Oxford were the better side. It was touch and go as to what tone with report would take, but I am delighted to say that a first league win since August has put a little positivity back into the club.

Wimbledon started with early pressure including a few corners, but with Oxford weathering that storm it was Sean Rigg who started to come on top with some great form on the left side of midfield in a 4-4-2. It was his run, cutting inside, which led to a free kick taken by Jake Forster-Caskey. The Brighton loanee curled it the wrong side of the wall into the top left corner leaving Wimbledon's Brown with little chance of making the save. Rigg created more chances, the best falling to Potter who failed to do anything useful with it. The Dons then managed to fashion some good chances which a better team would have taken. The U's could have conceded 3 or 4 by this point.


Jake Forster-Caskey's free kick was Oxford's opener and his third of the season.

Wimbledon equalised when they capitalised on some poor Oxford defending, typically from a corner which has been a weak area recently. Wayne Brown failed to deal with the corner and after a mini game of head tennis Harrison bundled in. They then took the lead when Fenlon took a speculative snap shot from distance which found the bottom corner. At this point some fans were accused of 'celebrating' the Wimbledon goal. I think it was more a sarcastic response to the criticism they got earlier to turning a 'hate Swindon' song into a 'hate Wilder' song, which was a stupid thing to do. Ironically this had the action of actually getting the fans behind the team and the team performance lifted to its best of the game. I do think some fans fail to understand that criticism of a manager does not mean lack of loyalty. Blind faith is not a good quality. I think anyone who turned up tonight was more loyal than those who stayed at home to listen on the radio. I don't buy the 'you don't like Wilder so your not a real fan' argument. Either way, recent performances and results have contributed to falling attendances and fan disharmony.

At half time, Heslop replaced Cox, a very risky and brave move on the part of Wilder, but one which paid off. Despite recent poor form, Heslop played very well, getting on the ball in midfield and driving the team forwards. It was really good to see this switch work out well. After Raynes had gone off injured in the first half, Brown followed to be replaced by Clarke who I was surprised didn't start after Brown's pooer game at Rotherham. Another game, another two injuries. You make your own luck in football, something is wrong with this.

Oxford drew it back to 2-2 when a Potter header was fumbled by the visiting keeper, and Deane Smalley was the quickest to react. Chances, corners, and possession continued to come, but OUFC had to wait until the 82nd minute for the winner, when Batt, then Craddock worked the ball into the centre, the latter crossing to Potter to tap home with ease. Wimbledon were not done and had several chances, unlucky to find the post and wasting easy chances right in front of goal.

Positives: Great result, not just in terms of the game, but in the context of the season. Heslop's improved form. On the other hand, Oxford gifted Wimbledon chances. Players were not closed down well enough. Another team would have destroyed us. The main thing is the players will draw confidence from the result, especially with a game against top of the league, in-form Gillingham on Saturday.

Oxford Team: Brown (Clarke 60), Batt, Raynes (Worley 33), Wright, O'Brien, Rigg, Forster-Caskey [1], Cox (Heslop 46), Smalley [1], Potter [1], Craddock.
Booked: Wright, Forster-Caskey. Sent off: None.
Wimbledon Team: Brown, Fenlon [1], Francomb, Antwi, Mambo, S Moore, Jolley (Johnson 76), Gregory, Harrison [1] (Strutlon 77), Midson, L Moore (Yussuff 61).
Booked: Francomb, Antwi, Gregory. Sent off: None.

Man of the Match:

Sean Rigg was already in my mind for man of the match at half time. He went a little quiet at time, second half included, but he made the difference. His crosses were top notch, he gave the right back a hard time, and he importantly created chances. It was great to see him back on the form he showed at the start of the year, and on the back of a great goal at Rotherham.

The opposition:

Most teams this season will look at Wimbledon's lack of points, and their huge negative goal difference and expect an easy win. Today they had no problem creating chances, and threatened in the air. Where they were lacking was in dealing with Oxford on the wings, and between the sticks I though they goalkeeper looked weak. He parried simple catching chances and gifted Smalley Oxford's equaliser. The Dons recently sacked Terry Brown who had guided them up from the non-league but was struggling at league level. What they mainly failed to do was see out a lead when they sat back. This might be their return to the 5th tier of the pyramid.

Around the grounds:

Exeter, Gillingham, and Fleetwood all continued their excellent form with wins. Wymcombe's failure to beat Plymouth kept them in the bottom two. Dagenham and Redbridge will be delighted with a point as Potr Vale. Overall, little change in the table.

item.title: Charlton Athletic 1-1 Blackburn Rovers
item.description: Rovers being a new chapter with Steve Kean, but the performance was lacking
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Jackson 27
1 - 1
Etuhu 16
The Valley, London
Attendance: 17,169
Dickson Etuhu scored for Rovers, finishing well after Gomes and Rhodes combined with quick passing.

Steve Kean's resignation less than 24 hours before kick off was a shock due to its timing if not its reasoning. His former number 2 Eric Black took charge and Rovers fans were in party mood with many wearing party hats and bringing balloons. Rovers started well enough, opening the scoring through Dickson Etuhu who finished off a lovely and quick passing interchange.

Rovers then sat too deep, inviting Charlton on. When a ball was crossed in, Pedersen fouled Cort in the penalty area. The shot was blasted straight down the middle and although Robinson dived to his left still managed to save it with his feet. Rovers defenders were slow to react and within a minute Charlton had equalised and the Blues didn't clear the ball. The shot was a little lucky as it took a deflection on the way in, but the outcome was deserved. This woke Charlton up and they continued to dominate the game, but never really threatened except for a couple of decent chances. Robinson made some good saves as the defence continued to allow shots to come in.

David Dunn's performance lifted Rovers and gave some impetus going forward, but came on too late to have a real impact.

The travelling support demanded changes to increase the attacking play, with Dunn finally coming on for Nuno Gomes. Dunn was the spark needed to see Rovers finish on a high, but his introduction was too late. No other changes were made, while Murphy had a quiet match and should have been replaced by a more potent threat such as Nunes or Rochina. Rhodes had a late chance that was just wide after a decent game linking up well with others. On the balance of play Rovers will be happy with a point but really should have come for more than a draw. All in all a poor performance that never really got going.

item.title: Kean's gone: a step in the right direction
item.description: Steve Kean unexpectedly resigns less than 24 hours before kick off
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
The soap opera at Blackburn Rovers took another unexpected twist as Steve Kean resigned on the eve of their away match at Charlton. Rovers fans will deservedly be in party mood in the capital tomorrow and I am feeling very optimistic about the mood and direction of the club and very much looking forward to my second trip to The Valley.

Kean resigns as Blackburn manager: possibly the greatest news headline ever.

Rovers fans have taken a lot of stick in the national media, particularly from southern journos. Meanwhile the newspaper reporters and TV presenters in Lancashire have understood the situation and taken a more pragmatic view of the situation. Notable critics of Kean have included Lancashire Evening Telegraph reporter Andy Cryer, and North West Tonight and Radio Lancashire presenter Graham Liver. And then there's the former players. Robbie Savage on FiveLive, Michel Salgado, Kevin Gallacher, all players who fell in love with the club and felt strongly enough to want Kean to leave. If you are not a Rovers fan and you are still not convinced Kean should have gone... would you want him at your club?

If your answer to the previous question is still yes, you are probably not fully aware of the facts. Here is a simple of Kean's achievements at Rovers.

  • Promoted from assistant to manager, due to dodgy agent Jerome Anderson having hands on role in club
  • Signed Myles Anderson, son of Jerome Anderson. Myles plays no games for the club before being sent off to League Two
  • Kean is banned from driving for drink-driving offence, then blames Rovers fans for setting him up
  • Sells Phil Jones, Chris Samba, and Ryan Nelson in space of 12 months. Rovers let in huge amounts of goals and get relegated.
  • Puts legend Michel Salgado into footballing limbo over the sake of a few quid
  • Tells media its only 1% of Rovers supports protesting against him
  • Takes team to Tottenham needing win to realisitically stay up. Has no shots on goal.
  • Relegates
  • Publicly slags off Sam Allardyce and is posted on YouTube. Allardyce starts legal proceedings
  • Signs three players he has never seen play before. East Lancashire is declared a colony of Portugal
  • Ends Rovers career with a 28% win record, the worst of any Rovers manager. Ever.
  • Is sacked by Rovers with statements prepared for release on Monday.
  • Mrs Kean begs for Mr Kean's job. Kean's job is saved.
  • Kean weasels his way out of Rovers job saying his position is unteneable. Well yes.. because of the 28% win record.
  • On quitting jobs tells two more lies: 1) That majority of fans supported him, 2) Rovers are in the automatic promotion places, they were actually 3rd.

So what was the final nail in the coffin? Well according to Rovers managing director Derek Shaw, club chairwoman Mrs Desai was disappointed to see Kean go. Is this to save on any possible compensation or genuine delusion? Global Advisor Shebby Singh, a notable critic of Kean, refused to comment on Kean's long term future after last weekend's defeat to Middlesbrough. Though a statement was released saying that Kean would be in charge at Charlton. He also travelled down with the squad on the Friday night and presumably checked into the London hotel. 8pm on a Friday night is a bizarre time to quit, which makes me think something has happened since this lunchtime to force Kean's hand. If the owners wanted him gone then last weekend was the time to do it. Why would they wait? I can only think some kind of player revolt was the final blow. I mean, why else would you travel down to London if you knew you were going to quit? Unless being a Scot he wanted to make use of the free hotel room.

The only other thing I can think of if the commercial side of it which was always going to be a killer. And for this Rovers fans can take the credit. Attendances which were plus 20000 last season fell to 13000 for the first four home games. With Kean not appearing to be going a planned protest for the following weekend would have seen even the fans who had already bought tickets not using those tickets and staying away. Commerical suicide to keep Kean, and this would have become more apparant as the week went on and ticket sales didn't increase.

So who next. Well first the unrealisitic targets: Capello, Redknapp, Ranieri, Benitez, Eriksson.
Now the club heroes with little or no league managerial experience: Tugay, Sherwood, Shearer, Flitcroft (doing alright at Chorley).
Now some more realistic prospects at a Championship club: Alan Curbishley, Mick McCarthy (not a fan).
I'd be surprised if we went for the poaching option. Who can say. All we know is it's exciting times ahead.

item.title: So what's going wrong at OUFC?
item.description: An attempt to look at what Oxford United need to improve on to progress to League One
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
I'm going to start this article by being up front and saying that I'm in the Wilder Out camp, but this article is not just an anti-Wilder rant. I was in favour of change at the top when we lost to Southend last season ruling out our slim chance of reaching the playoffs. Then I decided to shut up and get behind the players and manager. The fourth defeat in a row against Cheltenham which, I will admit I didn't watch, was the trigger for me to readvocate this. As I said earlier, this is not just a list of reasons for replacing our manager, but actually a compilation of various views expressed in recent weeks on Twitter, BBC Oxford, Jack FM, and of course my own opinions on last five matches weeks and the last few years.

Tactics, formations, and Plan B

The first criticism often made of Chris Wilder is tactics and the lack of a Plan B when things go wrong. Possibly a harsh criticism you might think as he gets its right more often than he gets it wrong. And when it does go right no one ever calls Wilder the master tactician who got it right. Or maybe you will look to a persistent, almost blind faith, in a 4-3-3 system which really is just a 4-5-1 with strikers playing as wingers. Potter plays well in this system, but Constable and Smalley are at their least effectual when they end up wide. On rare occasions a switch to 4-4-2 has been made and sometimes been the impetus to do better and sometimes made no difference. The tactics simply don't change from match to match. No matter who the opponent is, whether they are coming to park the bus, or to have a go at us, the formation and style of play stays the same.

Defending set pieces

Over recent matches a significant number of goals have come from the team's inability to defend corners, other set pieces, and crosses from open play. Every time an opponent gets a corner there is an sense of inevitability. The number of goals conceded is misleading to how bad the problem is. I can remember many matches this season where only the lack of quality finishing down at League Two level has prevented unchallenged headers being converted into goals. I can't pinpoint exactly what is going wrong apart from the easy with which we are allowing free headers, but I know that in training I would be making this a priority area. Given how bad it is at the moment, perhaps it would be a good idea to get every player back to defend corners. New personnel are also needed in this department.

Attacking set pieces

From direct free kicks we can be an exciting threat when Chapman and Leven stand over the ball, but for free kick from out wide and corners we simply don't threaten the opposition enough. When the team are playing well the number of corners we get is phenomenal and, especially when in front of the East Stand, can really get the crowd going. So it seems like such a waste when they come to nothing. A common mistake is hitting the ball too long. Or is it an organisational failure to have someone attacking at the back post to capitalise on this? This is a recurring theme for corners. Another problem is that the ball just simply always falls to the opposition. This suggests that players are in the wrong position or are too slow to react when mistakes are made.

Investment, and squad depth

Investment in the squad has been minimal. Ian Lenegan promised an end to the reliance on loan players. However our strongest team with a fully fit squad would only contain 1 new signing since last season. That addition would be Jake Forster-Caskey, a season long loanee from Brighton. Raynes looked good at first but has since been revealed to make too many crucial mistakes. Three other defenders to join are all loanees including Sean McGinty who was sent back after 1 minute of pitch time. In midfield Sean Rigg was not started today despite the midfield being decimated by injury and illness. Lee Cox is a long term loanee. Up front there have been no signings. Those in favour of no change will advocate the injury crisis this season (and last season, and the season before that...) and it has been a massive problem. Those in favour of change will argue that Wilder has had several years to develop this squad and make sure that there is sufficient cover. A caller on BBC Oxford argued that it is of course a squas game now and the squad isn't good enough even if the best 11 can be one of the best teams in the league.

Behind the scenes

The departure of Kelvin Thomas as chairman and replacement with Ian Lenegan, the owner who wants to take a more hands on role, was never going to see things stay the same. Lifelong OUFC fan and director Jim Rosenthal quit the board recently, with neither the outgoing Rosenthal, nor the club chosing to comment on the reasons. Obviously Rosenthal and Lenegan don't see eye to eye on something though no one knows what. I would never criticise Jim's commitment to or passion for the club, but as fans start to suspect major internal problems, I think he should demonstrate his love for the club by revealing exactly why he left the board. If there is something which might result in the club going through a dark age or god forbid see a return to the Conference, then it's no good saying a few years down the line what the problems were. They need to be revealed now so that slight damp patch on the club wall can be prevent from turning into a rot. If there isn't a major issue then he should also come out with that too, as it would be put a lot of fans at ease. Some fans think Wilder is the problem, and other think Lenegan is the one would should go. Apparently Lenegan has invested £4M recently which is good, but there is definitely something not right behind the scenes.

Falling attendances

This is a sympton of the problems rather than a cause. Back when OUFC were promoted back to the league attendances were hitting over 7000 for most Saturday matches. Even when we had won three in a row this season we were still in the 6000s. Clearly the post-promotion buzz has started to wear off after a couple of years, and the next home games, home to Wimbledon on Tuesday night, possibly on the back of a 6th defeat, could see it fall to 5000 for what I think would be the first time since we were in the Conference. It is a combination of performances and results which are turning away some of the more fickle punters.

Conference-level players

For continuity it was good not to have a massive clear out after promotion, but now it is time to say goodbye to the remainder of the players who have not moved on yet. Constable hasn't scored enough goals at League Two to justify his continual occupation of an offside position just when we need an outlet to pass to. Refs haven't taken to kindly to his passion either. Initially we thought it was bad reffing, but really he needs to stop complaining about pushing and just get on with the job of winning the ball in the air which he doesn't seem to do very well. Yes his is commited and gives his all, but this shouldn't cloud our judgment. After that you are really struggling to see where goals will come from in the strikers. Neither Smalley, Pittman, nor Craddock have looked like going on a proper scoring run in the last 12 months. Before that we can all name a long succession of forwards who were brought in and had no impact. Unfortunately two of the players deemed not good enough for League Two before they even had a chance were Jack Midson who amassed an impressive total for Wimbledon last year, and Dannie Bulman who is statistically one of the best players in League One.

Heavy defeats

Oxford have not had a big win in a very long time. Wins usually come on the back of a couple of goals. Even when playing really well, the goals just don't seem to flow. When the U's travel and concede a couple of goals, the heads seem to go down and the goals leak in. Last season we only score three or more in 3 matches. The same was done to us in 6 matches. This season we have conceded three or more in 4 matches already.

People will always have their opinions and it will be difficult to change people's minds; only results and performances can do that. If the person who is our manager does not change, then the manager has to make changes. If Wilder stays we can only improve if he develops flexibility. He needs new players, new tactics, and an ability to recognise weaknesses and improve on them. Back when we were winning and we had a minor blip, he would refuse to accept criticism from fans when giving interviews. A week ago when we had had our 3rd defeat on the trot he said he would not change his team based on the results. I doubt he can say or do either now and expect to keep his job. I'm not saying I have the solutions to the problems outlined above or I would be a football manager, but surely someone at OUFC should.

item.title: Oxford United 0-2 Bradford City
item.description: An apathetic and pathetic performance, with Oxford managing only 1 shot on target
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
0 - 2
Davies 52
Wells 68
Kassam Stadium, Oxford
Attendance: 6,032

Oxford went into today's match on the back of four straight league defeats, and in a lowly 16th in League Two. The task was made harder with an ever-growing crock list now featuring Jon-Paul Pittman and Adam Chapman. What really did it for Oxford today was the lack of commitment shown by the players and the lack of a plan B when things were going wrong.

The first half was a dire affair, with only one shot on target for each team. Bradford had a bit more possession in the final third but failed to convert any chances and did not look very threatening. What they did do very well though was battle, get first to the 50:50s (which Oxford did not seem to want to do), and give away the necessary little fouls needed to break up the U's passing. There's not really much more to say about the first half to be honest. Heslop set the ball up nicely on one occasion but blasted well over.


When Peter Leven came on the passing going forward improved (a bit).

Seven minutes into the 2nd half Oxford conceded from a corner. Again. This time Andrew Davies scoring to put the Bantams 1 up. In previous matches this sort of thing has stirred on the yellow, but no such comeback looked on the cards today, even when subs were made, Leven replacing an ineffectual Heslop and Sean Rigg replacing debutant Luke O'Brien who had a reasonable game at left back. A second corner on 68 minutes gave Bradford a two goal cushion which Oxford were never going to come back from. A free header in the box fell nicely to Wells who had the simplest of tap ins.

Leven was unlucky not to score from a free kick which was well saved by McLaughlin, and Potter missed making firm contact from a Leven cross. The only other opportunity fell to Craddock who sliced horribly wide. So plenty of people left early, boos at full time from sections of the crowd, a fifth league defeat in a row, and a difficult away fixture up at Rotherham next week. Wimbledon the following Tuesday is already starting to look like a relegation clash.

Oxford Team: Clarke, Batt, Raynes, O'Brien (Leven 62), Cox, Heslop (Rigg 62), Capaldi, Potter, Constable, Craddock.
Booked: Cox, Constable. Sent off: None.
Bradford Team: McLaughlin, Meredith, Davies, Oliver, McArdle, Reid (Hines 82), Atkinson, Jones, Doyle, Hanson, Wells (Thompson 70).
Booked: Hanson. Sent off: None.
Man of the Match:

I honestly can't really single out any player as having made a better contribution than any other (or any contribution at all). Clarke made a few half-decent saves, O'Brien didn't do much wrong before making way for a more attacking option. Lee Cox was the least worst of the midfield.

The opposition:

Bradford kept themselves in the play-offs today, moving up from 5th to 4th. They didn't show anything which suggests they are promotion candidates today, except for getting an easy win. I'm sure they are capable of playing much better, though they did create plenty of chances. What they do have is great determination and battling qualities so they should continue to do well.

Around the grounds:

League Two looked like a very boring division this afternoon. Gillingham moved further ahead at the top, Wimbleon won at Adam Park where I assume Wycombe fans are very angry at their team's start. Southend came back from 0-1 down to win against Exeter and climbed to 8th. Plymouth turned around a two goal defecit at the Globe Arena, beating Morecambe with three goals in the last 18 minutes, including 2 penalties.
