item.title: Bristol City 3-5 Blackburn Rovers
item.description: A cracking game of football, packed with defensive weakness, won by a side with too much attacking quality.
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Adomah 1
Pearson 69
Baldock 83
3 - 5
Rhodes, 28, 95
Nuno Gomes 55
Rochina 81
Dann 92
Ashton Gate
Attendance: 14,657

What a genuine priviledge to watch this game of football. The momentum of the games twisted and turned it way through the 97 minutes until Rovers had the decisive goals. It is a long time since I last was in the ground at a good Rovers performance, and this will rate as one of my all time favourite Rovers performances and matches.

Rovers made the worst possible start, conceding within 45 seconds to the impressive Adomah. Despite going 0-1 down Rovers played good passing football, and kept their patience. The tide started to turn and after half an hour a defensive mistake led to Jordan Rhodes being clear through on goal. His composed finish equalised the score and showed how good this player will be in the Championship this season. It was his first for the club in his second game. Rovers continued to dominate in spells and looked favourites to go on to win. A set back was the loss of two defenders to injury before half time: Marcus Olsson and Gael Givet.

Nuno Gomes took a great strike on the turn to put Rovers in front. He didn't put a foot wrong all match, but did tire towards the end.

Ten minutes into the second half Nuno Gomes put Rovers 2-1. With his back to goal, he turned and put in a low shot and the comeback had happened. Rovers kept pressing forward and looked likely to get a third, but Heaton in goal was in good form. Rovers then sat back and defended too deeply, inviting City on. Pearson stunned the away support to make it 2-2, finishing with great accuracy after another devestating run from Adomah.

Ruben Rochina came on and got what looked like a winner, creating a chance all by himself and picking out the top left corner superbly.

Rochina came on for Gomes and looked dangerous. He ran at the Bristol back four, finsing himself in the box but further progress was blocked by numbers around him. He composed himself, found enough space to get away a shot, and stuck it well out of the keeper's reach with his left foot. An unbelievable game at this point and surely Rovers would not win with only 10 minutes to go. Bristol City continued to look threatening going forward and Baldock scored a couple of minutes lack to silence the travelling fans. Another very accurate shot out of reach of Paul Robinson, but defensively the outfield players should have done more to prevent this.

Five minutes went up on the fourth official's board. Never before have I been more confident that Rovers had enough to outscore their opponents. It just seemed destined to happen. A free kick swung in by Pedersen fell to Dann in the box and his 92nd minute goal into the bottom left corner was enough. Football doesn't get any better than this. Well until the 95 minute. Rhodes was alone on the edge of the box. He continued with the ball but the keeper had the goal well covered and the defender was showing him nothing of the net to aim at. So Rhodes curled the ball into the only place where it could find the back of the net. 5-3 and there was no coming back from this. The scoreline reflected what a well balanced, free-flowing game of football this was. Very little in the way of fouls, no cards given, 50:50 possession, and what chances there were were accurate and efficiently dispatched.

With Rovers now top of the table and playing excellent football at a high tempo set by tika-taka passing from Murphy and Etuhu, I am confident this will be a good season. Tickets for Charlton and Nottingham Forest away are being ordered...

Bristol City Team: Heaton, Foster, Fontaine, Carey, Cunnigham, Woodford (Anderson 84), Skuse, Pearson, Adomah, Stead (Baldock 63), Taylor (Davies 71).
Booked: None. Sent off: None.
Blackburn Team: Robinson, Orr, Givet (G Hanley 37), Dann, Ribeiro, Pedersen, Murphy, Marcus Olsson (Martin Olsson 22), Etuhu, Rhodes, Nuno Gomes (Rochina 78).
Booked: None. Sent off: None.

Man of the Match:

Jordan Rhodes showed why Rovers spent £8M on him at the close of the transfer window. His link up play with Nuno Gomes was superb, and the two are forming a good understanding and partnership in only their 2nd game together. Both finishes were top class and he was in the thick of the action all game. Other chances he had were denied only by excellent saves from Heaton in goal.

The opposition:

Bristol City are an exciting team to watch. They are direct and fast in their counter attacks and Adomah caused problems for Rovers. Though defensively they are weak and against teams with attacking quality they will struggle. They may well stay up this season but I'm not expecting them to be challenging anwhere near the top.

On Tour: Ashton Gate, Bristol

Ashton Gate is an old fashioned stadium, each stand built as a stand alone piece of architecture. The Wedlock Stand is a singing terrace, furnished with token unbacked seats which no one uses. On the left stand the away fans, on the right stand the most vocal home fans. This close proximity of the fans makes the atmosphere electric, and the pitched roof reflects the sound back into the stand, creating unrivalled acoustics. The home fans sing to the away fans but they are focussed mainly on the game. This is in contrast to when I went to Northampton and the home fans there were more interested in abusing the away following than actually watching any football. Another thing that makes City a good away day is that many of the pubs seemed to have a good mix of home and away support and football shirts were not banned.

Around the grounds:

Blackpool slipped to second after failing to beat Barnsley, Tom Ince's quality earning them a point. Bolton got a vital win against Watford, while Burnley came back from 2-1 down to beta Peterborough 5-2, who now are rooted to the bottom with 5 defeats out of 5. Hull, Brighton, Cardiff and Nottingham Forest all won and are all in the play-off spots.

item.title: Oxford United 2-4 Exeter City
item.description: Defensive mistakes made it far too easy for a quality opponent.
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Forster-Caskey 55 (pen)
Potter 63
2 - 4
Cureton 11, 50
Bennett 27
O'Flynn 72
Kassam Stadium, Oxford
Attendance: 6,405

Oxford United fell to a second-straight league defeat, conceding seven goals along the way. It was also their first defeat at home this season. The U's got off to a decent enough start but when Cureton pick up the ball from just inside the home team's half, Jake Wright didn't know whether to mark him or the other runner. Wright was caught in no-man's land and Cureton lashed a spectacular strike into the top left corner. The second goal was controversial: A low cross was stopped by Clarke on the goal line. It wasn't even a difficult decision, it was obvious to everyone in the stadium that the ball as was in play. The linesman had other ideas and gave a corner. What was more inexcusable was Oxford's poor defending, allowing Bennett a free header. Exeter deserved their two goal cushion.

Exeter made it 0-3 after 50 minutes when Cureton again worked a piece of individual magic. Only then did the Oxford comeback start. Oxford now had their best 10 minute spell all season, tearing apart a very good side. Batt took the ball into the box and was felled, Forster-Caskey converting the spot kick. Continual pressure saw Potter score from close range. Deane Smalley then had a chance to complete an unlikely comeback, but headed over the bar, unmarked, 2 yards out. Continuing to push forward, Oxford were caught on the break, offering little in the way of defence to gift O'Flynn a fourth for his team.


Forster-Caskey scored his second of the season from the penalty spot after Batt was brought down.

The appauling linesman had one last impact on the game, killing off any chance of further entertainment in the game by flagging for an off-the-ball incident. The Exeter player fell to the floor like a sack of spuds after zero contact from Beano who had been booked less than 60 seconds previously. The red card means he will miss Burton next Saturday and is unappealable being a double booking. It had no impact on who deserved to win the game, but this linesman should be disciplined by the FA, he was awful and in a tighter game he would have a negative impact on a result.

Oxford Team: Clarke, Batt, Raynes, Wright, Capaldi, Chapman, Heslop (Craddock 55), Rigg (Pittman 60), Forster-Caskey [1], Smalley (Constable 73), Potter [1].
Booked: Forster-Caskey, Constable. Sent off: Constable.
Exeter Team: Krysiak, Woodman, Bennett, Baldwin, Coles, Amankwaah, Sercombe, Oakley, Davies, Cureton (Bauza 57), O'Flynn (Doherty 84).
Booked: Woodman. Sent off: None.
Man of the Match:

Not sure any of the Oxford players deserved this, so it has to be Jamie Cureton of Exeter.

The opposition:

Exeter are a great team. They will deserve to go up if they continue to play like they did today. In 2 and a bit years of watching League Two football, I can safely say that Exeter were the best team to have ever shown up. It would have been no great shame to lose to them if it hadn't been for inexcusable defensive errors which simply made their job easier for them. Jamie Cureton will get goals all season for them and is that extra bit of class needed to get out of this division.

Around the grounds:

Gillingham remained top of the league with an easy win at Barnet. Port Vale hammered Rotherham 6-2. Fleetwood enjoyed a big derby win at Morecombe. Other teams to pick up wins were Southend, Burton, and Northampton.

item.title: Oxford United 1-0 Swindon Town
item.description: A third win in 12 months over the scum, from a late Potter winner
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Potter 88
1 - 0

Kassam Stadium, Oxford
Attendance: 7,746

Oxford United recorded a third straight win over rivals Swindon Town thanks to Alfie Potter's late 88th minute winner. Sw*ndon came into the game on the back of an embarassing 4-1 defeat at Preston North End, a team not exactly endowed with form at the moment. Di Canio had managed to wind up yet another member of his playing staff by subbing keeper Wes Foderingham early in the first half, with the goalie having to make a public apology to keep his job. Oxford's good form combined with a League One opponent in indifferent form created an even and entertaining match. On balance the higher division team were probably the slightly better side, creating twice as many chances, but squandering just as many. Oxford raised their game and were deservedly still in the game as the final whistle approached. It looked like it was going straight to penalties, but sub Potter had the final say. Swindon defenders Ward and Flint collided when trying to head the same ball. Full credit to Beano who latched onto the loose ball, took it into the box, before squaring perfectly to the unmarked Potter who made no mistake.


Alfie Potter scored his second of the season against the unmentionables.

It is a rare occasion when a 1st round Johnstone's Paint Trophy match can generate a crowd in excess of 7000 and create such a thrilling atmosphere. Though this is down to the regionalisation of the early rounds which has been a clever move by the organisers. Next round: Away at Cheltenham.

Booked: Raynes. Sent off: None.

Booked: None. Sent off: None.

Man of the Match:

While James Constable did not really get involved in chances on goal, his physicality and bullishness created uncertainty in Swindon's defence, key for the mistake leading to the only goal of the game.

The opposition:

Di Canio's team was significantly changed from their defeat at Preston, but he doesn't accept hangers on, so on paper this team should have still won today. They didn't. Swindon fans were poor, rarely singing all game.

Around the grounds:

I could look up the other results from the 1st round if I wanted to but I simply don't care enough. The only important game was here, at the Kassam. And we won it.

item.title: CS50x: Introduction to Computer Science I
item.description: Signed up for HarvardX's online course through edX
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
At the start of 2012 I enjoyed MITx's 6.002x online course on circuits and electronics. This autumn (or fall if you are Atlantically-challenged) there are seven courses available online, offered by MIT, Harvard, and Berkeley. The three big players in the American university scene have combined forces under the name 'edX'. 6.002x is available again, and new courses are Solid State Chemistry, Software as Service, Artificial Intelligence, Quantitative Methods in Health Research, and MIT's Computer Science and Programming.

I have chosen to do Harvard's Introduction to Computer Science as it looks a little more advanced than MIT's from the description, and covers a wider range of programming languages. The course starts on the 15th October and can be completed any time before 15th April. There are 9 programming assignments of 15-20 hours each, 2 quizzes, and a final project, all of which will build up to an honor code certificate.

item.title: MK Dons 2-1 Blackburn Rovers
item.description: A cup exit at the hands of lower league opposition, but the performance was more worrying than the result.
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Chadwick 51, 67
1 - 2
Goodwillie 82
Stadium:MK
Attendance: 5,873

I drove the relatively short trip of 1 hour to Milton Keynes tonight to watch my first 'live' match of Rovers since the 0-2 defeat to Stoke two years ago. I watch a significant nubmer of games last year on TV and the internet, but this was my first chance to see some of the newer signings and experience the crowd's mood. Atmosphere was lacking for two reasons: 1) It was the second round of the Capital One Cup at MK, 2) Steve Kean and Venky's has literally sucked the soul out of the supporters.

David Goodwillie scored Rovers' only goal and looked hungry for goals when he came on.

A second string team was played with the main aim this season rightly being promotion from the Championship. You would expect these fringe players to want to play well to try to force their way into the team on a regular basis. You would particuarly expect this of the likes of Ruben Rochina and David Goodwillie. The senior players to give some solidity were Orr, Dann, and Etuhu. I am disappointed to say that the majority of the fring players did not make an impression and did not win over any fans tonight.

In goal, Jake Kean kept us in it with some good saves in the first half to make up for defenders being unable close down Dons attackers properly. There was too much backing off in defence and little good tackling. Bradley Orr was solid all game and was a reliable player. Scott Dann and Grant Hanley were poor, made mistakes, and looked unsure how to deal with attacking runs. At left back Marcus Olsson was fairly absent for most of the match and was beaten by his man too many times. He provided little going forward and was lucky to not be brought off.

In the first half the midfield was ok, Vukcevic wanted to get involved, while Dickson Etuhu was a class above every other player on the park. He sat in front of the back four and swept up everything, every little loose ball. He never gave the ball away, and when he picked it up he kept the tempo flowing and delivered penetrating passes to either wing. Soon after Rovers went 1-0 to Luke Chadwick's first of the evening, Etuhu was taken off, a decision unpopular with fans including myself. Without Etuhu the midfield looked weak, it did not protect the defender who frankly needed protecting tonight. Fabio Nunes doesn't seem to understand the pace or physicality of the English game yet and is not the sort of player you want on Tuesday night at lower league opposition. I would keep him in the reserves until he improves these aspects of the game and want to show a bit more committment. His only real positive contribution was the assist for Rovers' only goal.

Up front Edinho Junior and Rochina didn't test the keeper enough. Rochina was particularly poor on this occasion, before coming off for Formica. Edinho was replaced by Goodwillie who I was very surprised not to see on the starting lineup. Given the full 90 I think he would have had a real go at their defenders and given 100% as he is not getting starting opportunities in the league at the moment. MK were excellent going forward but there was always a hint that if tested their defence might crumble, when they gave the ball away to not particularly physical Rovers' forwards. Goodwillie's goal came from an unchallenged cross from Nunes and a relatively simple header which you might expect to be defended better. If we'd had more than a pathetic 4 shots on target we would have won this one. Compared to MK Dons' 11 shots Rovers lacked the enterprise and ambition going forward, happy to pass it back to the back four, even at two-nil down. At the time when we most needed goals, our tempo was at it's lowest and MK were able to keep the ball under minimal pressure.

Conclusions: Foreign youngsters win you nothing. Steven Kean is unable to even do the simple job of making sensible substitutions when a game needs to be won. Dickson Etuhu must be kept fit and play every game this season for Rovers to go up.

MK Dons Team: Martin, Otsemobor, MacKenzie, Chicksen, Willians, Gleeson, Potter, Powell, Chadwick (O'Shea 77), Bowditch (Ibehre 90), MacDonald (Lowe 74)
Booked: None. Sent off: None.
Blackburn Team: Kean, Orr, Dann, G Hanley, Ms Olsson, Jorge, Etuhu (Lowe 58), Vukcevic, Nunes, Edinho Junior (Goodwillie 58), Rochina (Formica 69)
Booked: None. Sent off: None.

Man of the Match:

Of the Rovers players there wasn't much choice today. Only given 58 minutes Dickson Etuhu was the player who kept us in the first half and would have been our best way of keeping the ball moving when we needed two goals in the second half.

The opposition:

MK Dons are an impressive outfit, they play the ball well, and have good pace in attack. They have confidence in their own abilities and no doubt they will be up at the top of League One again this season. With that division looking less strong than it did last season I would expect them to go up into the Championship.

On Tour: Stadium:MK

The newly built stadium in Milton Keynes is a great fan experience. Currently there are two tiers (but it is expandable to three) though only the bottom tier had seats. The top tier is having seats installed for the start of next season to increase the capacity, just in time for them to most likely be a Championship club. Around the outside of the ground it is a bit of a construction site, but inside I would rate it as the best stadium I have been to in terms of facilities. Seats are very confortable, and big with lot of space to walk past people in your row. The aisles are wide too and the food is reasonably priced. I love how you can overlook the stadium from the concourse at half time. My only criticism would be the lack of urinals in the gents, meaning that unnecessary queues built up (even though less than half of the seats were occupied in this section.

See the panorama

Around the grounds:

Shocks in round 2 came from Crawley coming from behind to beat Bolton, Coventry dumping out their neightbours Birmingham, Leicester doing the same to their rivals Leicester, and Swindon beating Stoke 4-3 in extra time in a match which had 41 shots over the 120 minutes. Oxford lost 3-0 away at Leeds at a team with too much quality and will be pushing for a place in the Premier League next season. Preston and Burnley both went through to make Rovers exit look even worse.

item.title: Oxford United 2-1 Plymouth Argyle
item.description: A game of two halves, Oxford destroying Plymouth in the first half, and holding on in a nervy second.
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Smalley 20, 23
2 - 1
Williams 74
Kassam Stadium, Oxford
Attendance: 6,906

Oxford United maintained their 100% record in all competitions with another win to remain top of League Two. Chris Wilder opted to go withe same team and same formation (4-4-2) that started the excellent second half against Southend on Tuesday night. Tom Craddock started brightly, curling a shot just over the bar in the first fee minutes. Plymouth's Hourihane caused problems in central midfield twisting and turning his way into the box only to set up an offside goal. Sean Rigg was United's best creative oulet, providing runs and tempting crosses and causing no end of problems for Nelson at right back. In the 20th minute his hard work in winning a ball in the corner of the pitch set up Craddock's shot which deflected into the path of an unmarked Deane Smalley who scored his first of the season. Just reward for his ball-winning in the air.


Sean Rigg played well down the left and set up the first goal.

Smalley and Potter were often 2 on 1 and Smalley's perfect runs offered great passing opportunities for Potter. the minutes after the first Potter broke free, overpassed it to Smalley, but the number 10 placed it past the oncoming Cole from a tight angle. 2-0. Now thunder started, the heavens opened and the game settled down. Plymouth played it around well but failed to create any further chances of note.

The second half was characterised by substitutions: Oxford's were bad and Argyle's were good. Wilder revealed in his post-match interview that Smalley had a groin niggle and Forster-Caskey came off as the result of what he called a 'very poor challenge' from behind just before half time. Beano came on for Deano and Heslop came on for Forster-Caskey but I felt that both contributed poorly. Oxford's passing started sloppily and the lack of tempo invited Argyle on. Oxford's only chance in the opening stages when Constable put Craddock through but he shot over.

Argyle switched their two full backs, preventing Oxford's attacks and providing good options forward. Robbie Williams pulled one back from a superb low free kick around the wall, no chance for Clarke. Pittman had a chance well saved, while Hourihane went down embarassingly trying to win a penalty. Plymouth had a few more chances but none were good enough to score. So Oxford hold on to stay top of the league but the feeling was more one of relief at the final whistle. Wilder refused to be critical of the players who came on, and while it was difficult watching in the final 45 minutes, I think fans should see the positives: we have not conceded from open play in the first four consecutive matches, we can tear opponents apart when we need to, and players who were average last season have stepped up their game significantly.

Oxford Team: Clarke, Batt, Raynes, Wright, Capaldi, Potter, Chapman, Forster-Caskey (Heslop 46), Rigg, Smalley [2](Constable 46), Craddock (Pittman 67).
Booked: None. Sent off: None.
Plymouth Team: Cole, Nelson (Berry 46), Purse (Chadwick 71), Blanchard, Bhasera, Young, Wooton, Hourihane, Gurrieir (Williams [1] 46), Cowan-Hall, Feeney.
Booked: Bhasera, Berry, Williams. Sent off: None.
Man of the Match:

Dean Smalley only got 45 minutes of football today, taken off due to the scoreline and as a precaution with groin worries. He won every header that was sent his way. His runs were intelligent. He brought others into play well. Most importantly he finished off two chances very well. His confidence will grow, if fit he will start the next game, and hopefully he can start scoring regularly now after a poor first season last year.
The opposition:

Plymouth Argle had made a bad start, carrying on from their decline last season (but they did stay up against all odds). home defeats to Aldershot and an away no score draw at Dagenham indicate this season will be a struggle for them. I still exoect them to be middle to bottom half this season but they can knock it around well enough to stay up comfortably. Nelson struggled against Rigg in the first 45, but the substitutes Berry and Williams were game changers and Carl Fletcher should take credit for turning the game around at the break. Williams has bags of experience at this level and looks like he should be starting games, rather than being on the bench.
Around the grounds:

Exeter had a great 3-0 win away at Accrington, while Cheltenham, Bradford, Port Vale, and Gillingham all kept the pressure on with wins. Wimbledon's appauling start continued with a 5-1 defeat at Bradford. Fleetwood picked up their first win and I'm sure they will come good as the season progresses. Southend failed to win again, drawing 3-3 at Northampton. The luckiest and unluckiest teams of the day were Wycombe and Bristol Rovers respectively. Rovers were embarassing Wycombe 3-1 at Adams Park before the match was abandoned under a stormy sky after 66 minutes, when a bolt of lightning struck the Dream Stand!

item.title: Oxford United 2-0 Southend United
item.description: We are top of the league and they are bottom of the league. Tom Craddock earns another 3 points with a superb double from the bench.
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Craddock 54, 87
2 - 0
 
Kassam Stadium, Oxford
Attendance: 6,001

Even before Southend had a player sent off, Oxford had dominated the early exchanges. A lot of early focus came through Forster-Caskey and Rigg on the left, Batt on the right, and long balls to Deane Smalley who was winning headers all night. Southend finally settled into their rhythmn and were making a good game of it. This was interrupted by Michael Timlin's first yellow card after 21 minutes which was full deserved after a committed, but late challenge. Then at 26 minutes Timlin tripped Lee Cox as he was breaking on the counter and received a second yellow. Both yellows were justified in the eyes of the law, though I was a little surprised to see a player sent of for collectively so little and felt some sympathy for the lad as he marched off from a game that could never be the same.

Southend naturally started timewasting, thought it was only really Cameron Belford between the sticks who was doing this. Their two banks of four sat back and looked organised and contained Oxford's attacks. What could be mistaken for a lack of ideas was actually clever patience, pinging the ball all around the park, waiting for mistakes, and tiring out the opponents.


Tom Craddock marked a superb second half substitute's apperance with both goals in Oxford's win.

Chris Wilder switched it to 4-4-2 from his usual 4-3-3 after half time, Tom Craddock coming on for Lee Cox who was playing well but sacrificed for the sake of the system. It worked really well. Craddock scored twice, on 53 minutes, Sean Rigg sending the ball across the penalty area and Craddock poking a foot out at it to send it into the net. Timewasting stopped and Southend had to come at the Oxford goal. This opened the game up and Oxford's counte attacks were exciting, purposeful, and looked threatening. In the 87th minute Craddock made it 2-0 after receiving the ball in the box from Rigg and firing low past Belford. It made the result more convincing even though the performance has already convinced the home fans that Wilder has brought in quality and is starting to get the best out of earlier signing. Even his tactical awareness was spot on tonight!

Man of the Match:

Alfie Potter was running the show, making his trademark runs with ease. Another trait which he showed today was his physical strength which doesn't at appear obvious. He was winning slide tackles, winning headers, and outmuscling opponents. A man of the match thoroughly deserved. Special mention to Tom Craddock who took his chance off the bench brilliantly. A certain to start on Saturday?

The opposition:

Let's make one thing absolutely clear, despite the provocative blog description, Southend will not be bottom of the league come May and will be challenging once again for promotion. Oxford's dominance tonight was only emphasised by what strong candidates for promotion Southend are. The fact that Paul Sturrock's job was already being taked about after a 0-1 defeat at home to Accrington Stanley shows what great expectation there is on them after last season's thrown away campaign.

Around the grounds:

York's late equaliser at Morecambe, combined with Craddock's second lifted Oxford top of the league on goal difference. They are joined in the automatic places by Accrington (defining the critics) and Gillingham (superb result away at Wycombe). Rotherham beat promotion favourites Rotheram, while Torquay and Cheltenham had to settle for a point. Southend are the only team without a point now. Plymouth, Barnet, and Dagenham & Redridge already fill up the lower places. Wimbledon finished last season poorly and a 6-2 defeat at Burton suggests they will be battling relegation this season.

item.title: Lightbox
item.description: A simple way to display large images as albums on your website
item.author: Tino Race
item.content: Lightbox2, by Lokesh Dhakar is an easy script to incorporate into a website. It displays images on top of your website and it's function is to provide a closer look at a picture by clicking on thumbnails. The script is completely free and only requires jquery, JavaScript, CSS, and a couple of image files. It is very easy to display images using Lightbox2, and I was able to convert the images in my blog to do so very quickly. By grouping images using a simple name tag they can be forced to display as an album which can be browsed through and closed, all without leaving the current webpage you are on. I also found the forum helpful where people explain how to mod Lightbox2 to do extra functions such as providing external links. The only mod I have used so far forces the image to change it's size to fit the screen so as to avoid scrolling. To see an example of how this works, take a look at Walk around Blaen Bran, Cwmbran, a previous blog post which has several image. Click on an image to see the album in action.

item.title: Bristol Rovers 0-2 Oxford United
item.description: A classic away performance on the opening day
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
0 - 2
Forster-Caskey 22
Potter 32
Memorial Ground, Bristol
Attendance: 7,451

A late opening of the Football League season saw a great first day away victory at Bristol Rovers. It was classic away performance as two first half goals, followed by strong defending and good organisation gave the yellows the three points. Jake Forster-Caskey scored his first goal for the goal on his league debut, curling the ball into the top left corner. Oxford continued to look the better team after a bright opening half an hour. Rovers were limited to shots from distance which did not threaten Ryan Clarke's clean sheet. The one occasion they took advantage of poor Oxford defending lead to their goal being ruled out for offside. Still, it was not great to see two free headers in the box and Clarke will be grateful for the assistant's ruling as he made an uncharacteristic positional mistake as the free kick was delivered in.


Alfie Potter's individual trickery created himself a fine goal.

Goal number two was a brilliant piece of counter attacking from Alfie Potter. Oxford fans have been used to seeing him pick up the ball in midfield and travel great distances unchallenged, but all too often the final result doesn't match the earlier hard work. This time Potter received the ball just inside the Bristol half, and ran towards the box. His progress was helped by a very clever run from Constable which allowed Alfie to shoot unchallenged, low and past the keeper.

Bristol Rovers made some early changes to tactics and personnel in the second half and looked more of a threat. The home support was good and helped tghem dominate possession, shots, and corners. The fact that Oxford contained this threat bodes really well for the rest of the season. There were no wobbles, no heart stopping moments, just good defence. The only criticism could be that when they gained possession it was wasted too quickly and the attacking threat and crowd could have been subdued more easily by holding on to the ball and frustrating Bristol this way.

Man of the Match:

Jake Forster-Caskey looks to have strengthed our midfield and is capable of special moments, such as his 20 yarder today.

The opposition:

Bristol Rovers have struggled against Oxford since the latter achieve promotion to the football league. They showed enough about them today to suggest they should be top half and sniffing around the play-offs. Their support never gave up and neither did their players.

On Tour: The Memorial Ground

The Memorial Stadium, Bristol, is really a rugby ground. It contains a proper football stand, a racecourse grandstand, and and a collection of temporary stands, one even with a canvas roof! Rovers fans will be glad their new stadium has been given the go ahead. No alcohol is available for away fans in the ground. There is a supporters bar at the home end, though fans are able to drink outside and make use of the space behind this stand. I'm not entirely sure what they do if it's raining!

See the panorama

The win was important as several promotion candidates posted three goal scorelines including Wycombe, Gillingham, Port Vale, and title favourites Rotherham. Accrington's shock win at Roots Hall will make Southend even more determined to come and get a result on Tuesday night.

item.title: Potato and Onion Harvest 2012
item.description: The first crop of potatoes have done very well. Onion quality is still to be confirmed.
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
On a typical British Summer Day I went out to dig up the first half of the potato crop, and harvest four of many onions. It was typical because at the end of harvesting I had to run inside as a strong thunderstorm started lasting about 20 minutes. From just 10 seed potatoes (see Easter Gardening), 3.43kg of edible potatoes have been produced, and this is just half of the total to be dug up. Not bad given that I didn't prepare or weed the ground that well.. The potatoes vary greatly in size from jacket potatos to tiny salad potatoes. I have already lifted four onion out of the 15 or so that are ready. Some of them bolted so I don't know how good they will be. The onion is the most versatile and useful ingredients in the kitchen and is used in every culture. Hopefully I can create some creative onion dishes and post the results here.


Nearly 3.5kg of potatoes in our first year of harvest. Chips? Jackets? Potato salad?.

And then the heavens opened so I ran indoors.

item.title: Oxford United 0-0 Bournemouth (5-3 on penalties)
item.description: Oxford score all of their penalties to dump the League One Cherries out of the Capital One Cup
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Oxford win 5-3 on penalties
0 - 0
 
Kassam Stadium, Oxford
Attendance: 3,788

It's been a long night at the Kassam Stadium, but one worth being at for the 3097 Oxford fans (not the 691 away fans). This match had no sign of being a pre-season friendly; it was played with full commitment from both sides. AFC Bournemouth were a good passing side, who play football in the right way. They created early chances and showed why they are in League One. Close range headers were sent other the bar, strikes inched past the post. Yet Oxford held their own and played equally impressive football, and matched their opponent's possession.


The sun setting over the missing 'West Stand'. A continual problem for goalkeepers in the spring and summer months.

The U's starting line-up featured some new names. Michael Raynes, signed on a free from Rotherham made a solid debut and seems to be forming an effective partnership in central defence with Jake Wright. Sean Rigg and Jake Forster-Caskey created good crosses and attacking space, while Lee Cox on loan from Swindon was replaced by Dean Smalley partway through the second half. Two other players who were like new signings were Alfie Potter, returning from injury at the back end of last season, and Tony Capaldi, possibly the greatest ever left back to miss an entire season through injury. Possibly. Alfie troubled his opponents, and Capaldi looked decent.

Penalties in front of the East Stand. Well taken penalties from Craddock, Smalley, and Rigg put Oxford 3-2 up. Ryan Clarke saved yet another penalty, this time from Pugh who has earlier angered the crowed by overdramatic whinging to the referee. A save the home fans especially enjoyed. Chapman, then Grabban took it to 4-3, with Damien Batt stepping up to take the winning penalty. He sealed a Man of the Match performance defensively and push forward, by scorign the winning spot kick.


Substitute Tom Craddock scored the first penalty. Some fans were warning others to duck after he skied his last penalty here.
Five scored, and the yellows march through to the second round. Not the biggest upset of the first round, or even the night, but another indication that Oxford can mix it with the bigger boys. The draw will take place tomorrow at 12:30pm on Sky Sports News. It will be seeded, so a big match is guaranteed. The lowest placed seeded team from last season is Crystal Palace who finished 17th in the Championship.

Oxford Team: Clarke, Batt, Raynes, Wright, Capaldi, Chapman, Rigg, Forster-Caskey (Heslop 104), Cox (Smalley 67), Constable (Craddock 93), Potter.

Man of the Match:

Damien Batt was superb all game. He was defensively solid and caused problems for Bournemouth down the right wing. It was fitting that he should score the match-winning penalty.

The opposition:

This competition is obviously not a priority for AFC Bournemouth, but they fielded a strong team and took the tie seriously. In attacks they looked like they were a division above Oxford and possessed good strength in the air. Up front they had some good chances but to be honest they should have finished them. It will be interesting to see whether this was an off-day for the strikers or if this is something that might make life difficult in League One this season.

item.title: Kayking the Hinksey Stream - Thames Loop
item.description: An overgrown, quiet back water through Oxford's floodplain
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
This kayak trip started from The Fishes pub in North Hinksey, near Oxford. The route started by going downstream on Hinksey Stream, turning back upstream on Weirs Mill Stream, joining the Thames heading into the city, then continuing upstream on Bulstake Stream, before rejoining Hinskey Stream and returning to the pub. I parked on the road outside The Fishes and walked through the field to the right of the pub where there is a ford providing an easy put in. There is access to the ford through a style and gate which was open and is about 50m further down the road. You can view the MapMyRun route page, or see a 3D fly through below.

I wasn't sure what to expect at Hinksey stream. I had a good idea that it would not be straight forward due to vegetation and water depth. I had read a view articles (1, 2) about the stream and no one had said they had failed to navigate it (though some talked of taking scythes and and cutters to get through). After the ford the water depth was good enough, even though it was mid-August and there had not been a lot of rain in the last week in this area. The route continued to be narrow and obstacles exist such as ducking under branches, avoiding brambles and nettles, and surfing reed. These were not common enough to prevent the trip being enjoyable and there was nothing that couldn't easily be got past.

Hinksey Stream is a relatively straight route. There are not many view of the area as the banks are too high to see over and densly vegetated. This is not why you should kayak down Hinksey Stream. You should do this because you can get away from everything and every one. Apart from a small party of kayakers who had stopped from brunch on the bank, you will not see anyone along the entire route. There are no paths along side it. No bridges across which are likely to have many people walking across. At the railway bridge turn left and go under it. You will be unlucky not to head a train thundering otherhead if you just wait a few minutes. You will then go under Abingdon Road bridge, then the Southern bypass. There are now two options to connect to the Thames. If you are going downsteam, continue on Hinksey Stream where you will join the Thames just north of a single track railway bridge. If you are going upstream, you can either continue as previously mentioned then turn upstream where you will meet Iffley Lock and the Isis Tavern. It would be worth a stop here as this pub can only be accessed by bike, foot, or boat. The shorter journey which I took turned upstream on Weirs Mill Stream.

Here the river widens out and is accessible to larger vessels such as barges. I went back under the noisy Southern Bypass and continued up to Weirs Lane bridge, where obviously there are weirs. I have no knowledge of the branches to the right, but I could not see easy and obvious bank access to carry around those weirs. Take the left branch and you will go past people fishing in their back garden. Once the houses have been left behind the land opens up and there is a less mechanical looking weir. It is simple a very wide drop, of about 50cm, and is is very wide. On the right there is an easy get out and it is only 2m to the other side to put in at the higher level. Now you are at the right level to join the Thames.

Here is where you will see the most people of the journey, as people on footbridges stop to watch at the sight of a kayak on the Thames. I was amidst sculls, rowing boats, motor boats, and Salter's steamers. Now the duration of the paddling against the current was taking its toll and it was hard work heading into Oxford. On the right, Christ Church Meadow. Up ahead, Folly Bridge. Here is the Head of the River pub which does not have access, but there is a punt hire pontoon which would allow you access to the pub. I didn't ask if you can get out here as I didn't want to stop. To go under Folly bridge, either left or right are both fine, though the left channel offers more interesting view, particularly of the buildings on Folly Island. Look out for the tower like building which has had turrets fitted on it! Going through Grandpont the area has a history of railway and industry though not obvious at first. On the left is a crane used for loading boats. The footbridge which is a bridge on a bridge originally carried gas pipes to the gas works which was on the north bank.

Once under the modern day railway bridge there is a footbridge on the left over Bulstake Stream, which is the final part of the return leg. The stream was flowing surpringly fast. On the right is the industrial area of Osney Mead. This gives way to scenery like I first found on Hinksey Stream. Narrow water, high vegetation, low branches. The turn off for Hinksey Stream on the left was smaller than I though it would be. I originally though it was a different waterway and kept going past it, but turned around when the route just 'felt wrong'. That and using MapMyRun showed me clearly that I had taken the wrong route. The pub was only a minute or two away now. For the first time on the entire journey the route became impassible. It was a good job that on the right was the car park for the pub I started at and it had a path through. So I couldn't return to the ford I started at but it was near enough. I walked into the Fishes in hope of a pint... but it was some stupid art festival and it was Sunday lunchtime. I didn't seem to be getting served at the bar soon, so I went home.

item.title: Crete: Day 7
item.description: The Palace of Knossos and Heraklion town
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Our last day in Crete. We visited the ancient Minoan Palace of Knossos in the morning, and then finished in Heraklion town centre before flying home. The guide book suggested going early or late to Knossos as it would be cooler and also you would miss the queues. Well it wasn't wrong. We arrived at 9:30am and there was already a hefty queue forming and the car park was filling out nicely. The place opens at 8am and if you can get there at that time, it is definitely worth it. On leaving at midday the queue stretched a very long way. Early starts will avoid the queues and also miss the mass-group tours led through the site. I can only assume the tours are free, but walking around in a massive group isn't my thing, I'd prefer to go around at my own pace (i.e. faster). We found the key was to go where the groups were not. The tours conveniently kept the majority of people together in certain locations at any one time, so the rest of the place was not too bad to go around. We started by queuing for the throne room, and then walked around taking photos, looking at the mix of original ruins and reconstruction work by Arthur Evans, and occasionally reading the info boards. There are mixed opinions on the reconstruction work done, but I personally think it helps you get a better idea of what the Palace was like when it was lived in, so this can only be a good thing. The site is much larger than Phaistos and it definitely the most 'must-see' attraction on Crete, but is certainly more touristy than its quieter sibling. Avoid the shops and restaurants opposite. They are over-priced. This was the only example of business trying to fleece tourists I saw all holiday (except for at the airport which was worse). In general Cretans are happy for your trade and will charge a fair price for souvenirs, drinks, and food.

Running on fumes now as I did not want to have to add any petrol to the tank at this stage, we headed back to the airport where we parked the car in the rental place. The drive into Heraklion was slow past one of two hospitals the town has (they are open on alternate days, obviously). The road was just a series of roundabouts, and despite being dual carriageway, the parked cars meant it was just one lane. The bus from the airport to town is reasonably priced. They charge per journey, so single journeys are not punished compared to returns unlike in the UK. Make sure you buy from a kiosk before boarding though or you will pay extra. The bus arrived in Heraklion and we went for lunch at Minos restaurant.

Heraklion Archaeological Museum is the place to see all of the best finds from Phaistos and Knossos. Sadly the museum shut for renovation in 2007 and in 2012 is still not open. The most important exhibits are on display at a temporary exhibition not far from the original museum location. While I have not seen the original to compare, the temporary place lacks any atmosphere and it too contemporary a setting for ancient relics. Visitors must not touch the glass or even the building's walls, or one of several man-like women will say 'do not touch'. Don't even dream of talking any louder than a whisper or these same women will very loudly shout 'Do not talk so loudly' without a hint of irony. The artefacts on display are impressive and there is plenty of information on each one. The best is the Phaistos Disc, a record of the Linear B script which has yet to be deciphered. A replica fridge magnet (only â¬1) now proudly adorns my fridge).

Other highlights of Heraklion are the harbour wall which we walked along before dinner and the market street where we bought 1 litre of raki â¬13 (cheaper than supermarkets). I was keen to spend the rest of the time sat by a pool, but this was not easy to find. A quick check of the internet showed that Astoria Hotel, close to where we got off the bus, has a 4th floor rooftop pool bar. The entry is free to non-residents, but drinks are expensive. There is no pressure put on you to buy their food and drinks whilst using their sun loungers though (but I wouldn't recommend openly eating your own food!)

And so a really great holiday in Crete had to come to an end. Heraklion airport is nothing like UK airports. If ever you whinge at the security and queues at Heathrow, wait until you have been here and then you'll understand that such complaining at UK airports is pathetic in comparison. Even their duty free is expensive compared to Birmingham. The flight home was quiet, so while we were given the cheap seats with poor leg room, as soon at the seat belt signs went off we upgraded ourselves to the comfy seats at the front.

item.title: Crete: Day 6
item.description: WaterCity water park and Skotino Cave
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Our last full day in the area of Hersonissos. We went to WaterCity, a water park situated a long way from any town and up on high land in the hills. By driving there early we were able to get into the park first. Tt helped that most people then immediately queued for lockers but we went for sunbed and rings. We were first on the rides while other faffed. Importantly getting rings early saved a lot of time queuing. Before a strict policy of giving away the ring after going on the ride was loosely enforced, it was difficult to acquire rings as selfish people kept them. Some even put them on empty sunbeds. These people are literally worse than Hitler. Even when tough rules came in as the park filled up, a German family held onto their rings despite my comments.

The park has an excellent selection of rides, though my only criticism would be that the lazy river is just too lazy. My top tip is to wear socks. They will get wet which is a good thing as the walkways can be too hot in that sort of climate. Make sure you go on the zip wire well before 3pm as this is when the wave machine starts and the zip wire closes. There were some very unhappy looking people, but...well... tough I wanted waves.

Once the waves finished we headed for Skotino Cave (aka Agia Paraskevi Cave). It is vaguely sign posted, and the entrance if on a dirt track down from a church in the middle of nowhere. The short walk into the cave is like something from Tomb Raider. There are bats and pigeons living in a massive opening in the ground. The cave is very big and requires a head torch to really get the most out of it. I climbed down into the echoic chasm and explored around. The temperature was the coolest all week and this was a real highlight of the holiday.

Our last dinner was in Piskopiano, the village where we started the holiday by watching Cretan dancing. We had spotted a great deal on a mixed fish platter for two and we rewarded with great views over Hersonissos and its bay. It was washed down with a carafe of retsina (the first of the week) and the now customary, free raki.

item.title: Crete: Day 5
item.description: Boat trip to Sissi
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Grateful for a later start this morning we walked back to harbour and chose the 'El Greco' boat trip for â¬20 each. First stop St. George's cave where you can jump off the side of boat, a lot higher than I thought it would be. We attempted to snorkel but the visibility was very poor and we were not there very long. Was it all the boats maybe that had reduced the visibility?



Then the boat went to Sissi across the bar, a journey of about 1 hour. The boat was very bumpy. I don't normally get travel sick, but I can admit to feeling nauseous on this journey and I wasn't the only one. We had two hours at the harbour town of Sissi. I had a quick lunch at Skippers consisting of big beer and toast. There was some excellent swimming and snorkelling here, and great views of waves crashing against the harbour break. It is a windy route from the harbour to the beach so it was just quicker to swim across. The main shops and restaurants are not on the beach side anyway. There was another opportunity to jump off the boat before leaving.

Im just grateful that this sequence of badly-shot videos of a boat leaving Sissi didn't happen to our boat!

Back to Hersonnisos, the crossing was still bumpy but better this time around. We got back just before 5pm and broke up the journey on the way home by stopping at the Palm Beach Club, a free entry pool bar. Every day at 5pm they have an outdoor foam party. We weren't their best customers; we sat on the fancy loungers and didn't buy any drinks before our long walk back to the hotel.

item.title: Crete: Day 4
item.description: CretAquarium and a night out on the town
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Hoping to avoid it being busy we set off for CretAquarium. Well... once I had found the car keys which turned out to be in the car door from yesterday. Entrance is â¬12. Sharks, turtles, jellyfish, stingrays, starfish, anything you can think of, they have (but not a whale, which would just be silly). Everything is indoors, in darkly lit corridors with brightly lit tanks, bringing out the colours more vividly. We were armed with two cameras, my DSLR and my iPhone. Without going into a manual mode the DSLR struggled to get good focus on the images it took under the unusual lighting conditions. The iPhone on the other hand. Well that took its most spectacular photos it has ever taken. Ever colour was as good as real life (if not better). Every image was in perfect focus. I don't know how it does it, but it was able to compensate for and even bask in the difficult light. The photos in the album below are my favourite from the entire holiday. My most favourite being the jellyfish.

At the end of the exhibit there was a video about life on the abyssal plain. It was a BBC documentary, dubbed in Greek, then subtitled with English. I had been aware of how life survived in the absence of sun in the food chain, but wasn't aware of quite how abundant or weird it was. After leaving the aquarium we went to the climate change exhibition in the exhibition centre close by as it was included in the admission. We then tried to drive to Skotino Cave but got lost too many times, so we'll give that a go another day. Instead I was happy to chill by the pool at our hotel with an audio book and a beer.

In the evening we walked in search of dinner out towards the harbour and then along the harbour wall. It was here we found the various boat trips. I was kind of glad for the complete lack of choice in destination. It made the decision simple. You can go on a boat at 11am to St George's Bay, then to Sissi, then back for 5pm. Or you can do exactly the same on a pirate boat. Or you can go on two other boats that does the same journey at the same times. Or you can go on a different boat which does the same journey but in reverse to avoid the other tourists. We then went to a bar offering two cocktails for â¬8. So we order one each and got four. Erm... we sent two back, be careful here, they interpret 2-4-1s in a different way to us!

For dinner we found a place offering a chicken grill, mixed salad, and wine for two for â¬19. The free raki at the end of the meal was huge. At the Irish bar Shenanigans, we got a free shot with big beer. At another bar they were offering 2 free shots and half price cocktails, and best of all absolutely no entrance fees to clubs or bars. Plus they don't put the lights on at 11pm and tell you to drink up!

item.title: Crete: Day 3
item.description: A drive to Phaistos, Matala, and a nice gorge
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Another day, another drive. This time to the south-western tip of the Heraklion prefecture. This was the further drive of the holiday, starting with dual carriageway to Heraklion, a well built, quiet, and straight single carriageway road, then windy roads through villages and mountains to get to Phaistos. Here is the second most important Minoan ruin on the island and where the famous Phaistos Disc was found (a record of ancient Linear B script). Minoan palaces date from around 1800BCE to 1300BCE though were not just posh residences for powerful people. They were working palaces and served as administrative centres for each region. This palace has no reconstructions, just the original ruins as first excavated in 1874.

Before leaving the UK I bought a second-hand Tamron telephoto lens for my Canon 1000D DSLR camera. It has a focal range of 70-300mm, which is significantly greater than the lens which came with the camera 4 years ago. This was the first opportunity I had to properly try it out. You can see some examples in the photo album below. The photo I am most pleased with was a macro shot of a praying mantis which was happily sat on a rock.

A short drive south took us to the monastery of Odigitria. It's a working monastery which is free to enter. The buildings are maintained in excellent condition and the interiors are beautifully painted. The main reason to visit here is to climb the Xopateras Tower. There are steps leading up the inside to a wooden ladder giving access to the spacious roof.

Continuing south for another few kilometres, there is a dirt track on the right leading to Ayiofarango, the Holy Gorge. The track is stony and cannot be taken too quickly due to potholes. If you see any cars parked by some trees, keep going. We stopped and walked 20 minutes from here before getting a lift back to the car from a French couple. We carried on driving down the track to the next set of parked cars. This was not the end of the track or the car park, but many cars found it was as far as they could go. Beyond here is a steep incline which on its own would not be impassable. However potholes on the incline make it very hard to get grip on the dusty surface unless you have built up some speed and have good acceleration (something my Seat Ibiza didn't have). I tried anyway but got stuck for a minute and was relieved that the car started rolling back down the hill. It's a 20 minute walk to the beach from here. Be warned, there are no shops. Nowhere to buy drinks or food. No toilets. And the beach is pebbly. Also Lonely Planet claims its 1km to the beach, actually its 2km. Apart from that the gorge in stunning, you will see caves, rock climbers, a dried out river bed, and your reward at the end if a quiet beach which only walkers or the odd boat trip can access. Along the gorge is another monastery. No wonder it is no longer functioning if you build your places of worship in such inaccessible locations!

Without much in the way of food or drink we didn't stay long. Matala is only just up the coast, and is a popular beach-side town. It has plenty of shops, markets, and tabernas, many with great views across the bay. On the north side of the beach are a series of caves in the rock. The caves were lived in by hippies in the 1960s and now you can pay â¬2 to walk around them. Waves were breaking violently, very close to the shore line, so it is difficult to get in and out of the water but once in they make for brilliant wave jumping.

Back in Hersonissos for 8.20pm, we walked along the promenade to find dinner. The restaurants are very competitive and the best deal we got was 10% off the price and the first round of drinks free. We opted for the traditional Greek dishes of Gyros and moussaka. Across the road we had a post-dinner drink at Hook's bar, so named because of the seating is in the form of swinging chairs outside under the star, overlooking the coast. They offered the now standard deal of 'big beer' for â¬2.

item.title: Crete: Day 2
item.description: By the beach at Elounda, walking, snorkeling. Plus some Greek fire dancing.
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Today we explored Elounda, a seaside town to the east. It is famous for the island of Spinalonga, an abandoned leper colony to which you can get boat trips but we did not go there. We drove from Hersonissos and it took 90 minutes. We started by snorkelling and saw anemones, fish, and a lone sea urchin. We then drove over the causeway to the island of Kavousi and started walking up a hill to get a view. The walk contained impenetrable walls and gorse and we gave up 2/3rds of the way up.

Tired and thirst we found the Hirona pool bar and enjoyed the luxury of Cokes and the Internet. The final thing we wanted to see was the sunken city of Olous by means of snorkelling. So we drove back onto the island and walked along the coast past a church where we entered to the water. There are a lot of sea urchins here so make sure you are careful or wear footwear as I did.

Back at the hotel we chilled by the pool, drank gin on the balcony and cooked pasta. The Team GB football was on TV. A 1-1 draw against Senegal, with Craig Bellamy taking the lead, but slack defending at end was two points dropped.

item.title: Crete: Day 1
item.description: A day in Hersonissos and by the pool
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
As we went for self-catering do to the bargain price of â¬169 for 7 nights, the first task was to go shopping. As a typical Southern European country, the only thing small supermarkets stock are ham, cheese, an entire aisle devoted to crisps, chocolate, and booze. The old woman was so shocked to see how much someone had actually spent in her store that we got a 5% discount card and a bunch of free bananas.

We spent the morning by the hotel pool and had lunch on the balcony of our room. In the afternoon we walked to beach where we found clear, warm water in a huge bay area. We set up on some sunbeds but were then accosted for money so moved on as there was nothing saying that there were charges. We walked along the seafront, some of which was through hotels and found Star Beach. This is a free entry pool, bar, and beach area which seems to be a party Mecca for German and Dutch tourists drinking beers in the lazy river and enjoying eurodance music all afternoon. There is security on the front entrance (but not the beachside entrance) to prevent people bringing in their own food and drink for 'tax reasons'. I'm assuming this is because they don't want to pay any (it is Greece after all).

We walked back through town past pottery shops, quad bike rentals, and tabernas, and stopped off for piÃ±a coladas in a bar. For dinner we walked up the hill to the quiet village of Koutouloufari where we found Emmanuel's, a restaurant recommended in Lonely Planet for its wood-fire oven lamb, cooked with bay leaves and rosÃ© wine. It was lovely and cost â¬13. We continued to explore and the next village is Piskopiano. There is a bar we went into to have a quiet beer (Mythos), but there was Cretan dancing that night. The dancing started in a civilised fashion, but it was not long before the plates were smashed and the floor set on fire. Audience participation was encouraged and I was chosen to go a Cretan dance myself. It was a very funny evening and an essential Greek experience on a holiday here.

item.title: Crete: Day 0
item.description: Leaving from Birmingham Airport and arriving in Crete
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Jo booked a half day off work for a 17:45 flight from Birmingham Airport to Heraklion, Crete. On the way up we stopped at the village of Gaydon. We had a picnic in the church's graveyard, areas which are always quiet and lovely for sitting.

At the airport there was a dispute at security over a liquid I was trying to take through. I had inherited an empty Russian vodka bottle that was 100ml, so ideal for taking on planes. Unfortunately the bottle was in Russian so cause d a lot of confusion over what it was and how much it contained. The bottle had 0.1 followed by an unfamiliar symbol. I tried to argue that the bottle was clearly 100ml by looking at it but I was told it could not go through. After going back landside to figure this out I spotted that it was 100cm cubed. I was then able to use my iPhone conversion app to prove that this is equivalent to 100ml. But surely if your job is solely to look at liquids coming through you would gain an appreciation of units and what 100ml looks like? Tino 1 Birmingham Airport 0. The other side of security contains the all-important free drinks tasting.

Turning up early at the Monarch check in meant we had unknowingly be upgraded to pseudo-first class. You don't get treated any better; you just get the nicer seats with a little bit more leg room. Flying out the UK on such a clear day with great visibility I enjoyed spotting towns and roads. I was able to work out where I was when I spotted the lake at Blenheim Palace and was soon able to recognised Oxford, and then had an amazing view of my home town of Abingdon.

We arrived at Heraklion airport at midnight. I went to the Olympic car rental stand to collect the car. I was surprised to find out about their fuel policy which is annoyingly in the small print of the booking. The fuel surcharge was 90 Euro, making it very expensive fuel. Having already paid a deposit there was little to do but pay it. Top tip: Do not use Argus car hire as booking agents as they do not make all the charges clear.

The Seat Ibiza was reasonable but had very poor acceleration. Driving is of course on the right, but actually this really means most people straddle the middle of the kerbside line like they are a Scalextric car. The hard shoulders are frequent even on single carriageway roads. I first thought this was weird and poor driving but then realised the following day that it is to allow cars behind to overtake more safely. If only slow drivers in the UK were more considerate in letting people past when they are driving too slowly.

Roads are not signed well so after leaving the main dual carriageway it was not long before we were lost in the villages. It did not help that locals had not heard of our hotel. We got sent up a ridiculously tight road to find a hotel that was not ours. Finally we got to Hersonissos, found Mareva Apartments, unpacked and had a beer at the poolside bar. We met Yiannis who was very friendly and helpful. He had a long night ahead, awaiting arrivals much later than our own. We got rave reviews from a group who were waiting for their coach transfer to the airport to go home. Shame one of them left their phone...

item.title: Glasgow's Museums
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Booking a late flight back on Sunday allowed an extra day in Glasgow to see the city and its museums. I decided the best way to get around was by Subway. Glasgow has the third oldest subway system in the world (after London and Budapest). It has changed little in appearance since its creation (unlike London's underground), except for a switch from rope to electric. It just looks magnificently retro, its colour scheme, the quiet platforms, the low tunnels. Even if you can get around Glasgow more easily by bus it is still worth a trip on this transport system just for the experience itself. The system consists of one circular line running in opposite directions. They are called the inner circle and outer circle. A day pass is very cheap (only a few quid), but the subway does shut early on Sundays (6pm). If you do go, be aware that taking photographs in the station is prohibited by byelaws introduced in April 2012.

The first museum we had actually visited the previous day. The Gallery of Modern Art is in an ornate building. There is a nice mix of objects and paintings. The highlight was a video showing a series of explosions, fires, fuses, balances, and swinging in a domino effect. It lasted over 30 minutes, so it must have been a nightmare to set up!

West of the city on the bank of the Clyde is the Riverside Museum which is a transport and travel museum. It has famous rally cars, sailing boats, trains, trams, and motorbikes. The motorbike top trumps game, using real bikes, is well worth playing.

On the east side of Glasgow is Barras market, a place to pick up second hand bargains, knock off watches and football shirts, and antiques. It is firmly in Celtic territory. We tried to get a free tour of the City Chambers but it turned out to be shut on weekends, despite the website saying they were open every day. The tours run at 10:30 and 14:30 and you can just turn up to go on them.

Our final museum was the Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum which is almost like a cathedral. It's an eclectic mix between the factual and the bizarre and is definitely a place where there is something for everyone.

Before heading home we had a dinner deal at Barolo Grill. I found it on voucher website, but they were offering the same deal at the restaurant irrespective of the voucher. A bonus of the trip was a visit to the duty free at Glasgow Airport where I invested in two 1L whiskies for Â£55 (Glen Garioch Founder's Reserve and Aberfeldy 12yo).

item.title: Graham and Alison Lewis's wedding
item.description: A wedding at Pollokshiels Burgh Hall, Glasgow
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
A long time ago I booked flights and a hotel cheaply in preparation for the wedding of Graham Lewis and Alison Eadie. My preference for travel would have been by train (sleeper) but the prices weren't even close to being competitive. So we flew from Birmingham Airport early in the morning by Flybe. Again I would have preferred to get to the airport by train, but the shocking service on Sunday evenings and high price meant I drove. The flight wasn't very busy and was only a small plane.

Arriving at Glasgow airport we got the bus in and had breakfast at Wetherspoons, with a nice selection of Scottish specialities. Lunch was free and kindly provided by Delice de France and O2. It was such a generous offer we returned the next day for more free food. We stayed at the Etap hotel on the bank of the Clyde. It took a long time to check in as there was an almighty argument with some guest and the manager. We shared a taxi with Pagey and Louise to Pollokshiels Burgh Hall, the location of the ceremony and reception. The hall is church-like, though the ceremony was humanist. It was run by a Scotsman who was funny yet had a strong gravitas.

This was followed by a champagne reception with quoits and Connect 4 while the hall was being cleared for the wedding breakfast. After the meal there was a Ceilidh which was very hard work as it was incredibly warm, and then a disco.

item.title: Olympic Torch in Oxford
item.description: The Olympic torch comes to Cowley Road
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Today the Olympic torch reached Oxford after starting in Luton and visiting Milton Keynes, Aylesbury, Woodstock, and Bicester. Fortunately for me it was running 20 minutes late, which made up for the 20 minutes I wasted at the bus stop. Oxford Bus Company had stopped running buses down High Street too early, so I waited for a particular bus when I could have got any of the previous four to go past. I was not the only person who had done this. The rude drive claimed there were notices at all the bus stops (there weren't) and their twitter account seemed more interested in telling me I was wrong than offering anything resembling an apology.

So now I had to walk through Christ Church College to get to Cowley Road. I was very surprised by how many people were walking in the opposite direction. Why would you not want to see the torch is it was only a 5 minute walk away from you? When I arrived at The Plain, the roundabout was packed with people in high spirits. Walking up Cowley Road I have never seen so many people packing out the pavements in Oxford.

We found a spot outside Sainsbury's. An ideal location as it provided a decent view with not as many people as closer to town. It also was convenient for gin and beer, and was the best place from which to walk to Morrell Avenue to see the torch again. The procession was more disjointed than I expected. Every so often a group of people would walk by, then a big gap. There were samba dancers, cheerleaders, and policemen on bikes giving high 5s. Then the advertisers: Coca Cola gave out free bottles of Coke, Samsung gave out free Union Flags. Lloyds TSB gave out nothing.

Finally after a long wait the torch came by, and then it was gone. It was an emotional moment, not so much because of seeing the actual torch but more seeing how many people had made an effort to come and see it. A quick walk to Morrell Avenue offered a second view of the torch with a different runner. It was great to see so many people proud to be British and delighted to see something they will never see again. Until tomorrow.

item.title: Cotswold Wildlife Park
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
As part of ACE week (alternative curriculum experience), Science ran a trip to the Cotswold Wildlife Park. It is one of the largest zoos in the country, near Burford in West Oxfordshire. It is a great place to visit, and around 4-5 hours is about the right amount of time to spend here. The park is split into several themed areas with on the best being the Madagascan area. The first attraction here at 11am is the penguin feeding and talk. When this finishes the meerkats offer the most popular feature. Meerkats of advert fame are a lot smaller than I expected, and the baby meerkats, being particularly small took most of the awes.

At the back of this walled section is the lemur walk through. Here you are told to leave bags outside, particularly if they contain food. Otherwise the lemurs will go for you! The lemurs jump around you and are quite happy fighting, completely disregarding your presence. The talk is at midday.

The safari area has the usual zebras, giraffes, ostriches, and lions (who were very sleepy and are getting very old). The insect area was closed for refurbishment, so the best indoor building is the reptiles. The petting zoo has pigs, but did not seem too popular. The food is very expensive so if you do go take your own. A special mention must be given to the aardvark.

item.title: It's all Greek to me
item.description: Started learning Greek in the run up to my holiday

item.content:
One the four previous occasions I have been to Spain, I have always spent some time brushing up on my Spanish, which is not fluent, but allows me to do at least some talking in structured situations such as restaurants.

I have visited Greece twice before (once to the mainland, once to Falaraki), but have never felt the need to make an effort to learn Greek. So I feel this is the year it will happen. I have borrowed a Teach yourself Greek book from the library and have been listening to the Michel Thomas series of language CDs. So far I can order a bottle of wine, an ouzo, and a water. That's one more thing than I'll need to be able to order this summer!

Physics is great because I already know a large number of Greek letters and their English equivalent, so pronunciation should be reasonable, and loads of Greek words are in English anyway so it is often easy to have a stab at what a written word means.

One week in Crete booked! Despite initially wanting to go all-inclusive, we identified Crete, specifically the village of Koutouloufari, near Hersonissos, as where we wanted to go. The price of a return flight with Monarch and a self-catering apartment was much more competitive than a hotel resort nearby. Plus we'll have the freedom to enjoy the local bars and tabernas, and not worry about spending a full day exploring the surrounding region.

We have taken out a few travel books from the library and so far identified quite a lot to do. There are water parks, aquariums, gorges, mountains, beaches, wineries, archaeological sites from Minoan times, and caves claiming to be the birthplace of Zeus.

We are staying at the Mareva Apartments. Every review I have read so far highlights how wonderful Yannis (the owner) and his family are, so I am looking forward to this hospitality.

I have had to renew my passport. There is a 2-3 week turn around, so I am hoping this is not delayed or there might be problems! The remaining things to sort are car rental so that we can explore as much of area around Hersonissos and Heraklion as possible.

item.title: England 1-0 Ukraine
item.description: Five games unbeaten, England qualify for the QF as winners of Group D
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Tonight Roy Hodgson defied the odds by taking his depleted England through to the Quarter Finals of EURO 2012 as winners of Group D. Not only that but England became the first team to have five different goal scorers at the tournament. 'Strength in depth' was not a phrase that sprang to mind when the final squad was submitted.

Ukraine started the game in a more positive fashion and were the better team, essential as only the win was enough for them to qualify. They came close on too many occasions for comfort, but it was relieving that either they were so far out that it was signs of desperation, or that Joe Hart was having his best game of the tournament so far.

Despite the way the game was going, the best chance fell to the rejuvenated head of Wayne Rooney. A delightful cross from Ashley Young, a free header from 8 yards, and two yards wide of the post.

Given the advantage in possesion which the Ukrainians were building, it was a very sensible decision to start to play it around the back before half time. It led to the inevitable whistles from a partisan crowd but it ensured England went into the break at 0-0. Psychologically they were of course winning.

After the interval Rooney scored the only goal of the game. A corner was only half cleared to Steven Gerrard on the right wing. The eventual Man of the Match's delivery had been superb all night. This was no exception. Such was the pace and accuracy of the ball that it took not one but two deflections of defenders, before deflecting off the keeper's hand to the head of Rooney. One yard from goal. Not even a hair transplant from hell could prevent this one.

The main talking point after this was a possible equaliser from Marko Devic. A long ball and pass found Devic clear on goal. He lifted it past Hart, but it was cleared heroically by Terry. At first what looked like a superb clearance was revealed to be a goal as it clearly crossed the line. However further replays showed Milevskiy to be clearly offside. Fair that Ukraine were denied a goal (still not made up for Germany in South Africa).

The pertinent thing was that the sixth official with a perfect view didn't give the goal! What is the point of them? Sepp Blatter: get video replays involved. NOW (but only if they would be used to show the Ukrainians were offside in the build-up too).

News that France were losing 1-0, then 2-0 to the already eliminated Swedes boosted spirits and significantly meant England would avoid the Spaniards until at least the final. Even Shevchenko in his last hurrah could not pick up Ukraine who now needed two goals. His frustration resulted in a petty yellow card.

Awaiting England are Italy on Sunday evening. The Italians have not looked special but have done the business and looked solid in defence. Like England. This might not be one for the purists. Or it could be a classic. Fingers crossed that the Greeks put out the Germans on Friday...

item.title: MITx 6.002x Final Exam passed
item.description: I have passed the Circuits and Electronics course of MITx's first online undergraduate course
