item.content:
At the end of a hectic half term on a stag do one weekend and a trip to South Wales the following weekend, I had to do my MITx 6.002x final exam. Sadly I have not had enough time recently to do full justice to the very end of the course. Though I am glad to say I passed with a B grade.

I did not have time to watch the final week of lectures which put me at a massive disadvantage on OpAmp questions. Also I had not been able to revise the final 5 weeks of content. This was because I was taking the final exam at the last possible moment and with no spare time in the previous two weeks.

I was extremely relieved to amass enough points to secure the pass so I kept going and through hard work got up to B. I kept trying to get more points but it became clear that it was not likely I could now get enough for an A so I stopped as I simply didn't have enough spare time to continue.

I thoroughly enjoyed this course and have learnt so much about the complexity of circuits that I didn't know before. Even if I never use it again it was really interesting to find out about some of the building blocks of analog and digital circuit which have applications in radios and computing.

The circuit creator was enjoyable but obviously the real practical element was missing from an online course. I am going to try to apply some of these skills, probably over the summer, and the most obvious thing to build would be a radio, something big and small boys have been making for the last 70 years.

item.title: Photo Gallery
item.description: Using HTML5, CSS3, and JavaScript to produce a browsable photo gallery for my blog
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
I've been keen to have a photo gallery on my blog for some time now. So I searched the web and found a large range of photo galleries which I liked the look of. The first two I tried were very nice but were a complete pain to get to work and were far too rigid in how they worked. So I ditched these and finally settled on this gallery on tympanus.net. The tutorial was well explained and the code was clearly laid out so that it was easy to edit.

First I set about replacing html links to images with some PHP script which searched my blog for images and wrote these links into the html. I then wanted to be able to link from the image to the relevant blog post so I added an extra button, and with a little help from JavaScript pro Jo, I got the link to work. The final step was solving the issue of the gallery not being circular when the number of images is not a multiple of 6. So I added some PHP which counts the number of images in my blog and only returns a multiple of six.

So that's where my Sunday went to, but I am really happy with the results, and I have learnt some JavaScript along the way. The front page now only has a few minor things to tidy up before it is complete, then I will need to do some improvements to the way the blog posts themselves are displayed.

item.title: Sweden 2-3 England
item.description: Theo Walcott led comeback puts England 2nd in Group D
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Theo Walcott inspired England to their first win at Euro 2012, scoring one and setting up another in a match they were losing. Andy Carroll scored first with a powerful header off a magnificent cross by Gerrard. England looked comfortable, though not special, for the remainder of a quiet first half.

Sweden's main strength was from set pieces, and it was from a free kick that they equalised. Strong determination from Ibrahimovic lead to the ball falling fortuitously to former Aston Villa defender Olaf Mellberg. Hart got his hand on the shot but couldn't prevent it going past him. Glen Johnson tried his best to clear it off the line but it was very diffcult for him and he could only play the ball sideways into the goal.

Moments later Sweden took the lead, again through Melberg with a header from a free kick. It was a ball England should have defended better, as Mellberg was completely unchallenged. It was not clear who exactly should have been marking him, but the Three Lions will need to be better organised against set pieces from better teams.

Cue Walcott's arrival. A corner was cleared by the Swedes but only as far as the Arsenal winger 20 yards out. His shot ended up at easy catching height in the centre of goal, but it was the lift and swerve that he generated which left the keeper completely unable to do anything about it. It was a quick response that took the wind out of Sweden's sails.

Into the last 10 minutes, Walcott burst in the penalty area and put in a cross to Danny Wellbeck. The ball was behind the United front man, but a combination of his quick thinking, awareness, and sublime touch enabled him to spin flick it into the net to seal a 3-2 victory. A goal to remember from a player who looks to have a very bright future. Steven Gerrard had a great chance to make it four, but his close-range volley was straight at Isaksson.

Roy Hodgson can take enormous credit for a difficult victory against Sweden, the first ever in a competitive match. His decision to play Carroll was a good one. The substitution of Walcott for the ineffectual Milner won England the game. Sweden will be very disappointed to lose a game in which they played well. To lose both of their games so far from winning positions must really hurt and they become the second team to leave the tournament.

item.title: Physics Wiki

They are incredibly simple to set up, students like using them, and they open up the possibility of students helping each other with homework. The wiki I have set up, http://lwsphysics.wikispaces.com, is a private wiki, but membership can be requested. I have started setting homework exclusively on this site. item.title: England 1-1 France

item.title: Cardiff and Barry Island
item.description: Checked out what's occurin' on South Wales' equivalent of Santa Monica beach (not)
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
A grand day out on the train, exploring the rest of South Wales. We walked to Newport station to catch a return train to Barry Island, home of Gavin and Stacy. The ticket allows you to break your journey at Cardiff, so we walked around the capital. For the second weekend in a row I picked the only sunny day to go to the beach, a masterstroke in shear luck.


Cardiff is a modern and vibrant city with trendy bars and modern sculptures.

Barry Island is not really an island, but until very recently it used to be. The construction of the Barry Docks formed a land bridge to the mainland and is connected by road and rail. The train has to approach the station very slowly due to a very tight curve off the mainline, and a steep incline onto the island itself. Alcohol is banned on the streets and there are no pubs (only a restaurant bar), which helps keep it a family location and prevents it being ruined. It is full of cheap tat shops such as Hyper Value (as mentioned in the GLC song Guns Don't Kill People, Rapper Do, 'I seen it in a documentary on BBC2, Shot to death outside Hyper Value, Guns blazin like Michael Caine in Zulu'). The beach is a wonderful expanse of clean and soft sand at low tide. Ice creams were amazing and excellent value at Â£1.60 per cone.


Barry Island's promenade is surprisingly nice, with ample free parking.

There is a headland, only 3 minutes from the beach with a superb view of the beach, but sadly also a view of the naff looking pleasure park.


The headland has steeply dipping rocks exposed at low tide, which I explored.

There is a pirate-themed crazy golf with a really good set of holes and by far the best theme a crazy golf course can have. I was pleased to be on the winning team.

Back on the mainland we had a drink in the Sir Samuel Romilly (an amusingingly named Wetherspoons as I am good friends with a couple who's names are Sam and Romilly) and watch the Dutch lose 1-0 to the Danish. Overall I though Barry was an excellent British seaside day out, extremely good value for money (not counting the 200 mile round trip from Abingdon), and if I was ever in the area again on a sunny day I would definitely go back.

item.title: Newport, you knows it!
item.description: Weekend in Welsh Wales is a winner
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
With Friday being the last day of half term and Jo having a day booked off, we planned a lastminute.com weekend away. We opted to go to the Brecon Beacons, but rather than staying in this national park I found that Newport would be cheaper and save at least 1 hour of driving. So we booked into the Etap hotel 1km out of the city and just off the M4.

Driving down was through some of the worst rain I've ever seen on the M4. This made me really glad we went for a budget hotel, not camping! First stop was Cwmbran. It's the Welsh equivalent of Milton Keynes. Its town centre was entirely planned and built in one go. It has a surprising mix of concrete, brick, glass, and stone buildings.


Cwmbran is a new town and is a huge shopping complex in the middle of the valleys.

It has quite a nice mix of shops. Wilkinsons, Marks & Spencer, and a range of value and charity shops. Best of all is free parking in a covered multi storey car park. It was not a surprise that it was busy with shoppers.

Next we stopped at the village of Caerleon, a site of a Roman fort which is now a free museum. Only the foundations of part of the gymnaisum and the outdoor swimming pool remain but it is enclosed in a sympathetic building and is subtly lit to give the impression of the pool being full of water. The panorama below didn't really work well in the low lighting conditions so it doesn't do justice to the atmosphere created inside.

I can thoroughly recommend the Red Lion next door, which provided a cheap pint of Green King IPA and main meals for under Â£3. Down a hidden alley of specialist shops we found a treasure trove of sculptures, including what clearly appeared to be the large Welsh lovespoon ever created.


The largest wooden love spoon in Wales?

The rest of the afternoon was spent in Newport after checking into the hotel. We walked a long way out of town to the transporter bridge, one of only two working examples left in the UK. I never actually know what a transporter bridge was until today. It turns out to be a platform suspended on cables. The platform is pulled horizontally across the river to the other side. It is free for pedestrians and a nominal Â£1 for cars. Council cuts mean the bridge will be open less frequently next year. I feel it would do a lot better if it was actually signposted from town as we only found it by knowing in advance of our trip and by using an Ordnance Survey map.


The Newport transporter bridge towers over the docks. A hidden gem outside of the city.

The economy in Newport is thriving.

On the way back I couldn't help but pop into Sports Direct to buy both the home and away England shirts. They were really good value and since buying them I really love the design and material of the kit. Later that evening we had a drink in the Tom Toya Lewis, one of three Wetherspoons and watched Russia annihilate the Czech Republic. We followed this with dinner at the New World Cantonese restaurant. It was lovely food and the manger was very friendly, though I wasn't too impressed with my fortune cookie.


My fortune was sadly hidden within a different cookie.

item.title: Physicasts.co.uk

item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
It seemed like a good idea to have my own personal website to host my Physics podcasts on, rather than uploading them to a school specific website. This is because it protects my personal ownership of the podcasts and also helps associate the professional identity with myself rather than the school. It will also help generate a larger audience if the website is not branded with a specific school.

So I registered http://www.physicasts.co.uk/ last night. This morning I completed the branding exercise by reserving facebook, twitter, google, and youtube accounts in the name of Physicasts. Annoyingly someone has already taken @physicasts on Twitter but they have never used it. Also Physicasts does bring up a few results on iTunes, but these are titles of individual podcasts rather than a series. Apparantly the authors claim to have made these podcasts in the 'back of our Physics lessons'. God bless the American education system. While its not a water-tight branding exercise (like Jade off of The Apprentice last week), I feel confident it won't overlap with anyone else now or in the future.

I have started work on the website as well which I am hosting myself. It still needs a few more days work on it to really get it going, but I think I've hit a programming wall this afternoon and need a break.

item.title: Pagination of XML data using PHP
item.description: How I reduced the number of blog posts which load at once
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
As this is now my 59th blog post it seemed like a good idea to restrict the number of posts which load at one. This required 'pagination', the ancient art of making pages. So I started work on this when I got up this morning. I made some PHP script which calculates the total number of relevant blogs, then how many pages it needs to spread them over. Another part of the script uses the current page number to work out which post it needs to display first.

After conquering this, it was fairly straight forward to use the variables and a foreach loop to generate links to the appropriate number of pages. Initially I had tried to look for a copy and pastable solution, but actually it was easy enough to work out what I needed to do and I have improved my PHP skills as a result.

item.title: Tag Cloud
item.description: Using PHP to create a tag cloud from my RSS feed
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
This has taken quite a bit of time to make, but I am very happy to have completed a tag cloud for my blog. Not only does it look like, but it also adds essential functionality for any decent blog. It also provides a nice overview of what I have blogged about for the reader. While I have nothing against things like Blogger and Wordpress, I set myself the challenge of making and hosting this website entirely by my own means. I am really glad I did this because this has forced me to learn a bit more PHP and after this afternoon I feel I could write some code from strach rather than copy, then past, then see what happens.

To make the tag cloud I coded the script to create a string consisting of tag names from my RSS feed. The code then word counts the tags placing them in an array, orders the array, then slices the top 25 tags and alphabetises them. Finally the piece de resistance is using the array to determine the font size for each tag based on how frequently the term is used.

I have posted my code as a text file if you want ideas on how to make your own tag cloud. I have explained why I have included each part as I am not a PHP expert and there are probably other (more concise) ways of doing this. If you have any feedback on how it is coded or have any suggestions on how else I could of coded it, I'd be grateful for a comment.

item.title: Personal Development time
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
The rest of today was personal development and reflection time. I used the time to develop my podcasting skills. I produced a revision podcast on the Electromagnetic Spectrum for Y10. The first aspect to a podcasting lesson would be planning a script, so I got a revision guide from the National STEM Centre and started planning. What I would say. While it is possible to edit and remove mistakes from the audio I learnt that it is much easier to do the podcast all in one take and plan very carefully in advance what you will say. I find it very difficult to talk into a microphone even though I am quite comfortable speaking in front of people, so I would probably write a full script which I could just read out until I became more comfortable doing this. I used a textbook and a rough script as a prompt so remind me not to forgot anything important. I ended up with 27 different files which I had to either delete or edit in!

Using Audacity to edit, I removed stray words, sections which I repeated to improve on an earlier attempt, and sections with gaps of silence. What started as 16 minutes of raw footage ended up as a neatly produced 7 minute mp3 file. I used 64kbps mono encoding which is good enough for speech. I used noise reduction to compensate for the wind that was picked up by the voice recorder. I have bought a TASCAM iM2 microphone which plugs into an iPhone and gives broadcast quality sound recording. I have make the podcast available for my Y10 students to download by creating a public dropbox folder. The link is http://db.tt/9iMvsgyb. Next week I will set my Y10s a homework of listening to the podcast and writing down 5 key points they learnt from it. I will also print out QR codes for the students to stick into their planners to give an easy link to the file

I really enjoyed podcasting. I will make it a focus for next year's Performance Management and try to get everyone in the department to make at least one podcast each by the end of next academic year.

item.title: Webtools and Freeware
item.description: Free websites and downloads that are useful in the classroom
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
The following are all free downloads which could be useful in Science teaching

Stellarium

Stellarium is a free open source planetarium for your computer. It shows a realistic sky in 3D, just like what you see with the naked eye, binoculars or a telescope. You can change you location, go backwards and forwards in time, and find out information about what you are looking at.

Scratch

A visual programming tool for kids. My school's Year 7 ICT course spends a third of the year using Scratch. In Science it could be used to make a game to revise a topic. A higher level use would be modelling (e.g. making a ball falling under gravity). This is would really make kids explore their understanding.

Tracker

You can upload a movie file (.avi or .mov) such as projectile motion. By advancing the video frame by frame you can click on objects. The software is quite powerful and can analyse the motion.

Wink

Wink is a screen recording tool which can make files (e.g. video tutorials). It creates three files (.html .js .swf), all of which need to be present to work. Recording uses the keyboard to start/stop recording. It works fine at 8fps. After it has created the project you can add text boxes onto individual frame. You can add 'next' and 'back' buttons to allow the user to control when the video advances. You can even add images or audio.

Webtools

We then spent 30 minutes reviewing webtool posted on the above website. There are loads!

Prezentit
Allows multiple users to collaborate on a PowerPoint and then the file can be downloaded onto you computer. (Research in groups)
Wolfram Alpha
A massively powerful computational engine - can solve any question
Kodu
Like Scratch but you can make games in 3D and play on your PC or Xbox (for ages 8 and up)
Debate Graph
A way of visualising debate - is it suitable for schools? I will have to test it later.
PaperRater
Perfect for proofing coursework. It will check for spelling, grammar, quality of writing, and origintality. This will vastly improve the quality of coursework in A-Level Physics from our weaker students.

item.title: Top tips for using ICT in schools
item.description: How to use Excel, PowerPoint, Aminations, SMART Notebook (a bit better)
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
SMART whiteboards have more interactive software than PowerPoint which is very much just a presenting tool. The toolkit within the SMART notebook software has activity generators, such as keyword match, category sorting, anagrams. The software can be used to create a backbone to a sequence of lessons with files attached. PowerPoint can be used as a tool to aid taking of independent notes. By setting up a presentation with a progress bar on an automatic timer, students pulled out the key points and took their own notes. PowerPoints can be saved as pps files for running as a show. Quiz and hyperlinks can build a pseudo-webpage. Excel can be used to make student friendly graphs so that they just put in the data and the graphs are made automatically. Visual Basic macros in Excel can randomly choose students. Worksheets can include QR codes, which students could scan with their phones (e.g. to get help and check answers, or link to external websites - so many great possibilities). There is a wealth of useful apps but as protractors, distance measurers, seismometers, colour detectors. Some great ideas which will need to looking at tomorrow.

item.title: Podcasting: Audio recording and editing
item.description: Making simple audio podcasts in lessons
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Richard Hollingham came into the NSLC to run a session on podcasting in lessons. He is a former senior producer for BBC Radio 4's today programme, but is now a freelance science journalist, writer, and broadcaster. The first thing he advocated was the simplicity of audio podcasting over video and I agree with him. He demonstrated an audio podcast made by some students. The quality was very good and they clearly enjoyed making it. They have posted their podcasts on Rothamsted Radio. One group wrote a script for the introduction and end. Another group were reporters and asked questions. The format was Jingle, intro, report, ending, and jingle. They were recorded seperately then edited together rather than doing it in one 6 minute recording. Editing was minimal to put the sections together. Scripting a list of questions in advance helped but it was only looked at the end of the interview as a check that everything had been asked (as it is important to listen to the intervewee). Questions like how, why, when are good, but 'To what extent...' is more open ended.

I made my podcasts using VC Audio Pro (a Â£5 app for iPhone), which does not require iTunes to transfer audio over WiFi. Others on the course used a Handy Recorder H2. We recorded an interview with Dr. Feelgood in three sections and the app as very easy to edit together.

The final challenge was to make a scientific podcast, recorded all in one take. We aimed it at Y7 teaching food chains but it had a slightly humorous element to it so I wouldn't actually use this in a lesson! It is 3:17 long and is entitled Rabbit Watch.

item.title: Videos
item.description: How to make a timelapse video
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Video lab 1 investigated the potential for using the iPod touch in Science. We use a free app called 'Motion pictures' which I have downloaded onto my iPhone as well. It records video, allowing you to set the number of frames, how often frames are recorded, but the playback frame rate is always 30fps. I recorded 180 frames, 10 seconds apart to record two ice cubes melting (one on a metal tray, one on a plastic tray). This involved a little maths to calculate the number of frames needed to compress the event from 30 minutes down to 6 seconds.

PicCollage is a nice app allowing the user to arrange, crop, and resize photos onto a collage which can be posted on Twitter or saved onto the iPhone's camera roll. Here is the collage I created. If iPods were being used in Science it would be a nice way of recording evidence of work such as during a practical.

We then used Stop Motion HD to make Wallace and Gromit style animations. We explained how ice melts on plastic and metal surfaces. It took 30 minutes to make 17 seconds of footage. I then recorded audio over the video and published it on my youtube channel. There is even a making of to be included in the DVD extras! Other groups also used plasticene modelling as well as drawing on a board with marker pens. We kept the iPhone still by using a retort stand and remote shutter (the earphone's volume control takes a still image each time it is pressed). Now we just need a class set of ipods...

item.title: RP2 Day 1 (Afternoon session)
item.description: Disseminating gap tasks, GPS data capture, and personal development time
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
The following is a summary of all of the gap tasks that members of the ICT Innovations 2012 Course have done since February.

Gail: STEM website and training

Gail has been working on a STEM Club web for her school. She also went on a course to help her provide external INSET. She trained other teachers to use Picture trail, Picasa, and most impressively Prezi which is a zoomable PowerPoint with great potential for mindmapping.

Cathal: Chemistry wiki

Cathal's wiki used code from Widget box. He also used picture trail to make a nice rotating box as a starter activity. The wiki was for KS5 as he thought that Y10s didn't have the maturing for this level of independence. He created a page for each student, and used the pages to communicate with students and parents. Assignments were uploaded, and answers where uploaded later. His students have started supporting each other on the forum (a built in widget on the wiki). A help page allowed students to instantly feedback which sections of an assignment they needed help with after Easter.

Alan: VLE

Alan set up a page on his school's VLE (Moodle). Students used phET to get data, make spreadsheets to do analysis and then upload the assignment onto the VLE. He shared the success criteria for a project via the VLE. He set up a revision forum for Y10 students where students can ask questions. Traffic lighting was done in a spreadsheet. This was very nice as it was done by entering one letter, but colour coded the list and allowed them to filter out the green statements. He bought goosenecks and webcams to create pseudo-visualisers. They cost Â£20 each to make and his department currently has two. He has agreed funding for Word Wall after demonstrating to the heads of various departments and is getting someone from the company in to demonstrate it.

Nicky: WikiSpace

Nicky's presentation used Prezi and was very impressive. She has worked on her VLE but at her school both teachers and students struggled using the VLE. She started with a wiki. Her school has invested in online homeworks. Her classes have used glogs (an online poster creator), Prezi, Xtranormal (storytelling), and used WordWall. However she mainly worked on Wiki. Y11 students' wikis were very successful. Y9 enjoyed it but probably didn't learn as much. Nicky recorded video in two free periods to make a Y6 taster activity - something Lord Williams's could do for Flippy the Fish (a similar Y6 day).

Peter: AS Wiki, Datalogging, Word Wall

Peter's department has purchased some new datalogging equipment, which is now tied into practicals in their schemes of work. He has convinced other departments in his school to supply money for Word Wall (citing PSHE as a good example of liking this and providing money) but is having problems sourcing the remaining money from the school itself! He did some modelling of half life using a popcorn maker (great idea!) and has a lovely selection of practical ideas on his page on the course wiki. His own wiki page set students the task of posting a resource that helped them understand a particular section of the topic. The wiki is protected so that only his students can access this which is a sensible thing to do for my wiki.

Zed: Imaging

Zed (an ICT technician) used timelapse feature using free software he downloaded to photograph a Magic tree growing crystals. The software added a date/time stamp. He then put these photos into a video. He showed science teachers at his school how to use the software and they plan to film seeds growing. Students have created podcasts (audio and video book reviews) . He is planning to get students to set up a website and upload the podcasts each week. He is also doing a project with feeder schools , working on podcasts and showing others how to use this technology.

Mine: Webcams and Website

My presentation

Katie: Word Wall, imaging, storyboarding

Her school had Word Wall already, so she started using it. It was easy to put students into groups. She got her students to make a quiz which was then used in another class. She used visualisers to do basic imaging (such as looking at the side of a match box in a Friction lesson). She pushed for interactive workbooks (Go Science) to be made available for students to use in school and at home. Her classes made interactive storyboards, including one where students looked at how to stop Global Warming. She found that the students had more confidence doing this instead of having to act it out.

Christine: many fingers in many pies

The presentation again made lovely use of Prezi. She dug out and dusted off some dataloggin equipment and used it sucessfully in Chemistry lessons, but it only works on 1 laptop! She liked the TTS digital microscopes but bought their visualiser instead. Her A-level students used Photobucket. She enjoyed blogging, and recommended Yola. Her students have all had to make websites. Her Y10s had to teach a revision lesson, and put their revision resources onto the wiki. She also used PBWorks as an alternative wiki site. She will be using Labbooks exclusively with a class next year as she has acquired some laptops. A project she is working on is a KS4-5 transition science network. A university student was given the task of developing their Physics website. Also she has done a project with NTU using inkpads. Christine has bought some HueHD webcams, used Etherpads, Prezi, Xtranormal (resulting in tremendous explanations), and CorkboardMe.

Jack: Webcams, Google drive, Datalogging

His school has several HueHD webcams, so he trained people in his depertment to use them. He also takes photos on his phone and puts them into dropbox to display on the projector. He created an interactive resource for KS5 Physics using GoogleDrive. He can see which files have been downloaded and how frequently so he can monitor revision. He has some DataHarvest sensors on order but had problems using previous sensors due to a network upgrade to Win7, so he has not been able to instill confidence using this yet, but will do with the new equipment. He showed pictures of his use of visualisers (exploring concepts such as solids, liquids, gases, and orbits of Earth/Moon).

item.title: Paul Hunt's Letter to Venky's
item.description: A letter leaked by Sporting Intelligence from Paul Hunt to Venky's calling for Kean to be sacked
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
The day after Blackburn Rovers were relegated from the Premier League after 11 years, Sporting Intelligence have leaked a letter sent by Paul Hunt, the deputy CEO of the club. Deputy CEO, yet the club has no Chief Operating Officer. The letter was allegedy sent after the Bolton game which saw the biggest protests against Kean and was the no going back point in his relationship with the fans. Not a single point of his ten point plan has been actioned and that is why the club is in a financial mess and got relegated. The link to this was placed on the Lancashire Telegraph's Rovers forum but was removed by the Venky's Evening Telegraph under the continual threat of being shut down by Jermone Anderson's who has blocked all free speech on his dispicable role at the club. Below is the full letter (which I can only assume is genuine).

Wednesday 21st December 2011

Paul Hunt
Deputy CEO
Blackburn Rovers
Ewood Park
Blackburn
Lancashire

Madam,

I have been your senior officer at the club for 6 months now and I feel that I must now write to you to ask you to make some significant changes to save the club, perhaps from relegation but also perhaps from administration. In twenty years of the Premier League there has been only one side that was bottom of the league at Christmas that has survived relegation at the end of the season. With the bank closing in, I fear that they will look to foreclose and have the potential to implement financial restrictions upon the club that could (as a worst-case scenario) enforce administration. I have kept quiet for a time now out of utmost respect and I trust that you realise that I am only emailing you now as I want what is only the best for Blackburn Rovers and the owners. I am very much of the opinion that we can save the club and I have always been very supportive and positive towards the owners. Therefore I hope you know that what I am saying is considered, honest, constructive and from the heart. I ask that we instigate all the changes below in this 10 point plan. If we do, then I guarantee that, come the summer, the club will be in a much stronger position than it is now. This will give the owners the following benefits: A richer asset in the club as a whole A happy, strong and valuable playing squad Peace of mind that it is being run admirably Protection for the Venky's brand and the BRFC brand The full backing of the Premier League Deliver the community a club to be proud of A devoted team of staff

1. Promotion to CEO
I am aware that that when we met in April, we said we would look at this within the first year. I believe now is the right time to promote me to CEO. The Deputy title is confusing to staff, supporters and media. I am confident that I now have the knowledge to be able to deliver strong progress. We have a great club, good team and an excellent range of staff that I feel can take this club forward, given the right support from the owners. Naturally, with extra responsibility I would like extra salary and I would be happy with a relatively modest increase with the promise of a good bonus and increase in salary in the summer that would reflect the improvement in position. I am currently the lowest paid senior club official in the Premier League.

2. Owners to invest in the club
As you are aware Barclays have asked for the owners to put Â£10 million into the business. This needs to happen and I am confident that this could only be a loan as we would increase the value of the club significantly. With all the speculation in the press the playing staff value and overall club value is depreciating on a daily basis. By putting an end to this the owners would be protecting their investment, putting their trust in the executive team and the club. The position with the finances is a cause for grave concern. Auditors KPMG have put as many obstacles as they can in the way of signing off the accounts due to their concerns. We continue to try and work with Barclays but they are very quickly losing patience as we cannot give answers. We have been forced to agree to additional spending against our wishes (Christmas hampers, sponsoring the Princes Trust event etc) and I am fearful that the situation will only get worse. During January we need additional funding to pay wages etc. Scottish club Hearts did not pay their players in November and have effectively breached their contracts. By law (supported by FIFA) the players can now annul their contracts, seek other clubs and still chase the club for payment of their wages. Clearly, the club will not receive any fee for any transfers. See link http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/football/spl/2011/12/10/hearts-stars-told-they-can-walk-away-from-club-now-over-unpaid-wages-86908-23623969/ You may also be aware that HMRC (tax authorities) have been chasing Portsmouth Football Club for a debt they owe. HMRC have made a technical mistake in law and therefore cannot claim the money they are owed. They will make sure of course that the next football club that falls out of line, won't be so lucky. We need to make sure that this club is not Blackburn Rovers.

3. Manager to change and report to the CEO
Publicly I have been asked to support the manager and I always have as I personally like Steve. I have supported him from the start and have been desperate for him to do well. However, I am now of the opinion that it isn't working and he is ready to go. He has lost the crowd and as a result of this evening's game has lost the dressing room as well, the players no longer want to play for him. It is a shame and disappointing but we must act now to save the club. The board should be asked their opinion in who should be the new manager. The board has over 60 years football experience between them, it would be a travesty not to rely on that experience for the biggest decision the club will make this season. The new manager should now report into the board who then recommend and endorse his wishes to the owners. Allow the board to protect the owners from the media, supporters etc.

4. Trust the executive, bring us in
Give the executive team at Ewood Park, the latitude and authority to run the club. Everything at the club needs to come through either myself, Simon Hunt or Karen Silk, both Karen and Simon are excellent appointments. We have vast experience and with Vineeth as well, I am sure we have a winning team. The owners must learn to trust us. I am enjoying working with Vineeth and although he has little experience in football, he is quickly learning. I am trying to establish him with all the other staff too and am introducing him to the Heads of Department on an ongoing basis. I don' t really think for one minute that the owners will allow this club to go into ruin but without knowing this for sure, we need to be prudent. However, if we had more information on your plans, strategy and thoughts going forward (after assisting you in formulating that strategy of course) then we can support and deliver growth. Without knowing the plan, we will of course be guarded and suspicious. With our fiduciary responsibilities as directors, if the club goes under, the directors (including Vineeth, Mahesh and Gandhi Babu) are all potentially personally liable for that failing and the courts could take our houses from us. My family do not deserve this.

5. PR just from Ewood
Another big issue is the PR and the fact that a lot of it in the past has come from India, without our knowledge. ALL press statements need to come from Ewood Park with me as the spokesman. That way we can control all the output and protect the owners. I will take on an experienced PR consultant who will advise the board and owners. It will be someone who will be aware when any negative stories are about to hit the press. We must now remove the club from being headline news for the wrong reasons. A full PR strategy needs to be instigated from January 1st that re-engages the owners with the supporters, the owners need to trust us in this regard as we know our customers. As owners you are not protected. Use the board (and manager combined) as a buffer zone to the media, the bank, the fans and we will protect you. I want to tell the media that what they are printing is not true but the truth is that I do not know. It is clearly evident that neither yourself, Bala or Venky currently feel comfortable coming to Ewood Park. If we as an executive team had more say, day to day running and authority, we would be able to support you and take all the criticism ourselves. The damaging story in the Mail on Sunday has caused players, staff and the supporters much concern. We need to invest time in stopping leaks leaving the club.

6. Regular visits to India
To be able to understand the strategy and to assist the owners, the executive team of myself, Simon Hunt and Karen Silk must visit India once every two months as a minimum. This way we can be together on all issues and help to craft them with our experience. I am happy for the new manager to be a part of that delegation and would welcome his input. I am very concerned that I have not met with you properly during the six months I have worked at the club. You have asked me to deal with things locally but to be able to do this, as I have asked before, I need a greater understanding of your aspirations so I can deliver on them. If you keep me informed and learn to trust me, I can be your mouthpiece.

7. Regular visits to Blackburn and Premier League games
The owners must attend games in Blackburn as often as possible and I would suggest that at least one of the owners is present for at least a quarter of the games. The staff needs to meet you and get to know you too, whenever I have met the owners, I feel warm and strong and you instil in me the fight to face challenges and win. The supporters also need to meet you and we need to get the message of solidarity out there as quickly as possible.

8. Hire and Fire
The executive team at Blackburn Rovers must be allowed to hire and fire staff. We will of course ask for the owner's opinion for senior positions but we must be allowed the latitude in this. In Simon Williams we have someone who is against the owners and spreads the word wherever he can. I am disappointed I was not allowed to remove him from post in the summer, when he and the rest of the staff were expecting it. We must act soon in this regard and look to review other positions and then give the staff great morale.

9. Lost revenue and brand equity
We are losing fans and customers at an alarming rate. I am very concerned that fans are voting with their feet and not attending, not purchasing and not engaging with the club. Research shows that only 5 percent of ex season ticket holders will ever return. We are losing sponsors and suppliers. I am concerned we will lose Umbro if we continue to manufacture Rovers shirts in India for the RoverStar programme. Their contract specifically disallows this and we are putting at risk 800k pounds of annual revenue. The Blackburn Rovers and Venky's brands are both suffering terribly. Whilst there are negative goings on such as protests, complaints, media stories, unhappy fans etc, then both brands are losing brand equity and consequently, losing value. I am also concerned that the Premier League will intervene soon as they may take the view that their brand is being tarnished by association too. It is all reparable of course but we must start to act now by building bridges with fans and the media as above.

10. Support is necessary, Final thoughts
I am disappointed that we have not managed to progress as I would have liked over the past 6 months. I for one was very excited to be given the opportunity and wanted to assist the owners in delivering strong progress for the club. However, we have been too busy fire fighting (protests, media intrusion, finance issues) to do this so far. As you know, I like to be proactive but the current climate only allows us to be reactive. I feel impotent as I am not asked by yourselves about my opinion on matters. I joined the club to make a difference, not to sit by and simply action instructions. I appreciate that my advice will not always be acted upon but I am disappointed that I am not asked. I have a great deal to contribute and have great experience. I won't get it right every time but will always do my best and learn from any mistakes. My concern is for the staff. They have put up with a lot recently and are still supportive. They live in the community and are being asked questions by their friends and family but cannot answer them. They are also being challenged at the games and when they come into contact with fans. Most are junior or part time staff who are feeling under pressure. I am concerned that they are going to become too stressed and will look to get jobs elsewhere. We have some great staff and cannot afford to lose them. I may be speaking out of turn here, but I am also concerned that no one reports everything to you, that is, everyone tries to report positive news and are not overly forthcoming when negative news needs to be told. By not having the full details, anyone would find it difficult to make decisions that encompass all the facts, all of the time. I am sure that if you were exposed to the full story, no matter how negative sometimes, that you would do the right thing. I need to be able to report a little more readily to you and on an infinitely more regular basis. Please don't view this as me questioning the owners unjustly. Please be reassured that I do question things, it means I am doing things right for the club and the owners by not accepting things lightly. This is how I work and how I must continue to work to get the best for Blackburn Rovers. With my experience of Blackburn now and my previous experience at three other prominent clubs, I do feel as though my suggestions come from a position of strength and can make a huge difference to life at Blackburn Rovers. I would very much appreciate an opportunity to speak with you on these points by invitation to India. Without instigating these points it will get more and more difficult to deliver progress for the club. I call on the owners to act, to play their part in the investment that puts all our minds at rest, and then allows me and the executive team to initiate all of the above points for the greater good of Blackburn Rovers. I look forward to hearing your thoughts.

With very best wishes for a bright future,

Paul

item.title: Why Chris Wilder should go
item.description: While still mathematically possible, Oxford's season is over in disappointing fashion
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
I've not blogged about Oxford for a few games now. I guess it's because the results (and performances) were just to depressing. Just 3 points out of the last 6 matches is a pathetic return. Even if the unthinable happened, Oxford would neither deserve nor have the form to go up through the playoffs. Once again no team has particularly out played us. But the lack of power and strength up front has been even more obvious in the last month. Too many loan signings. Too many weak, skillful players, inexperienced forwards. Not enough Akinfenwa-style fatboys who can bully and use their sheer weight to force the ball in the back of the net. Also we don't cheat enough. It's the way the game is going and we're always on the end of the bad decisions, so it's time we started cheating and being unpopular in the league.

For me the only step forward now is Wilder out. He's taken the club as far as he can. It's all well and good saying that he's improved us year on year, but how many strikers has he brought to the club who can't score goals? Too many! How long has his 4-3-3 system caused us to dominate games yet not score enough goals against teams who park the bus? Too long. Where is plan B to be seen when we go 0-2 down to Southend or Hereford nick a flukey goal? No where to be seen.

Newcastle were heavily critisied when they sacked Chris Hughton due to the fantastic job he had done at the club in his time there. However Mike Ashley realised that past form doesn't mean you can indefinitely keep improving. He realised that someone with more experience of managing in the top flight was needed. Does anyone in the universe still think Chris Hughton should be Newcastle manager and not Alan Pardew? A similar situation at Ewood Park when Venky's realised Sam Allardyce could never lift Rovers above mid-table. Unfortunately they replaced him with a worse manager, for whom 19th place will be a good achievement because at least he moved us up from 20th earlier in the season.

So Oxford: get in someone who has league two silverware experience, someone who will bring in the fat goal-scoring centre forwards, someone who can instill a 90 minute mantality in the good core of players we have, and most importantly gamble some cash to build a decent squad so we don't have to rely on uninterested loan players when the inevitable injuries start mid-season. And most importantly, no hard feelings and a big big thank you to Chris Wilder for what he has achieved in his time here.

item.title: Progress towards completing the eCPD: Mid-April update
item.description: A summary of how close I am to completing the eCPD
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
1) Word Wall

Word Wall in installed in all of the classrooms I teach in. I have used Word Wall to create seating plans for my Y7 classes. I've created a starter and a plenary (both definition matching exercises)
  • Question for Word Wall: Can I use the swapper function to sit together m/f pairs?
  • Use the seating plan to randomly choose people to answer questions.
  • Use the full range of activity types with a Y7 class.
  • Get another member of the faculty to create an activity and use it in a lesson (and get feedback).
  • Get feedback from another teacher, a TA, and students about the use of Word Wall with a Year 7 class.
  • Demo Word Wall in a faculty meeting at the end of the year once my trial is complete (after RP2).

2) Physics Website

The Physics website is hosted. There is a sensible URL redirect set up. The relevant documents which students will want to download are hosted. I have done a questionnaire with my two classes to find out what they would want from a website (this pretty much tallied with what I already suspected). I have done some exam analysis on past paper questions and fed this into the website's database. I have used the query function to bring up a list of past questions suitable for revising a particular topic and used these to target revision in a lesson.
  • Link all documents
  • Sort out the navigation menu bar
  • Complete exam analysis of paper papers and add to database.
  • Get feedback from students on use of wiki at end of the year.
  • Start setting up accounts and the home page of the wiki in preparation for Y12 post-exam lessons (after RP2)

3) Webcam

I have had a webcam installed in my lab at lower school. I have found out which other departments use this sort of technology (English - visualisers)
  • Contact English and ask for a list of ways in which they use their visualisers.
  • Use the webcam at least once during a demo.
  • Mark a piece of homework, some an example on the webcam, and get students to improve work based on what they've seen.
  • Get feedback from students and staff on the use of the webcam in my lessons.

item.title: MOSFETS, Capacitors, Inductors, and signal delay
item.description: Weeks 5,6,7: Getting ahead before the mid term
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Over the last week I have spent a lot of time working on 6.002x, working through three week's worths of course material in the space of 1 week. My motivation was to get ahead on the material rather than completing homeworks the day or two before to give me a little breathing space for when I go back to work next week. Also there is a mid-term exam at the end of April and I want to give myself a couple of weeks to revise for it and try more example questions as I am still not 100% confident on being able to solve all the various types of problems without the hints given on the discussion boards. Through a combination of luck, skill, perseverance, and blatantly fully worked solutions on the discussion boards I am still running on 100% on both homeworks and labs up to the end of Week 6 (which will be the content of the midterm), and only one question left to complete on Week 7.


Bar chart showing my progress in MIT's 6.002x Circuits and Electronics course. Note all the 100%s!

In summary: Week 5 looked at the MOSFET, introduced originally as a simple switch dependent on the gate to source voltage, but now seen as working as an amplifier over certain input voltages. This used both large and small signal analysis techniques which confused me a little and I will need to revisit in revision. Week 6 introduced the capacitor which I found a little easier than Week 5 but the homeworks were still difficult. Week 7 looked at the inductor and the reason for signal delay in circuits - its because most components actually act as capacitors. The week 7 homework was really easy, perhaps intentionally as its just before the mid-term?

item.title: Oxford United 0-0 Gillingham
item.description: Nervous and average performace, but still in the the playoffs.
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
As the season draws to the close, and after several games of outplaying opposition, particuarly at the Kassam, without picking up 3 points, the pressure and nerves are obvious, both in the players and the fans. The performance today was not spectacular, and fewer clear cut chances were generated than usual. Those that were were either criminally wasted, or resulted a goal line clearance. A 0-0 draw is a worse result for Gillingham than the U's as it keeps them 4 points off 7th with only 3 games to go. At full time is was looking like a poor result, but news that Crewe had only drawn 2-2 at relegation strugglers Macclesfield meant Oxford remain in the play-offs tonight. Two of the last three are away (Plymouth and Port Vale), seperated by a home fixture against Southend (currently 5th and potential play-off final opponents if the league remains unchanged). If we get 7 points out of those we deserve to get promoted, if we don't we deserve to fail to even make the play-offs. The end of the game was marred by another shocking refereeing decision. The ref had done extremely well up until that point, but with minutes to go Oli Johnson was through on goal with a chance at a shot. Why would he dive, it was a certain goal? He was tackled from behind, the defender got nothing of the ball and the ref blew the whistle: yellow card for simulation. Bottled it, sorry ref but you are once again out of your depth in lowly League Two.

EDIT: On Sunday, Ashley Young dived for the second match in a row to win a second penalty in a row. Oxford cannot appeal Johnson's booking even if TV evidence proved he was fouled. The FA will not penalise Young for being a diving cheat retrospectively. Where is the consistency? Where is the justice. Fans are turning off football as they realise that most results these days are decided by whom the referee likes more and which team has the most balls to take a dive or dive in for a tackle they shouldn't if they think they can get away it.

item.title: Easter gardening
item.description: Creating the structure for an alpine garden, and planting asparagi and potatoes
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
The second week of my Easter holiday was shown as 5 days of continuous rain so forgive me for not planning anything. As it turned out, every sing day between Tuesday and Friday was gorgeous and sunny. So I took advantage of this and blitzed the garden. The main focus of my efforts was digging up the lawn around the pond to provide a neater edge and make it easier to mow. There is now a tidy border which I have planted with some bulbs and will plant with some colourful ground cover in the near future. The removal of turf extended beyond the pond and was covered in weed suppresent. Next month when money is a little less tight we will cover it wil gravel and create an alpine garden. I did further tidying by digging in the pond liner, covering the edge with more sandstone slabs, and tidying the outdoor electrical cables supplying energy for the pond lights and the shed.


The west-facing allotment, with four potato trenches, and a greenhouse and tomato house newly positioned.

The asparagi plants arrived on Thursday so we now have 13 of these bare rooted plants in raised beds in the allotment area. On the opposite side of the allotment I dug four trenches in which I planted 20 seed potatoes. Other plants added included two tayberries and another gooseberry to add more barrier between the alpine and allotment areas, loads of summer-flowering bulbs in random places, and a couple of honeysuckles to climb up the arbour.

item.title: Northampton Town 2-1 Oxford United
item.description: A disappointing defeat to a team we clearly outplayed
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Sixfields is a strange place; like the Kassam, only there are more chain restaurants and fast food places. And the stadium is in a massive hollow. As usual Oxford filled the home team's ground for them with a strong away following. I spent a good deal of time in the pub before the games witing for kick-off. Its a strange pub as it was half filled with families eating dinner and half filled with football fans. And it took an age to get served.


Sixfields on a Friday night. The oddest location for a stadium I have ever seen, it is in a bowl in the middle of a retail park.

Oxford were by far the better team for 70 minutes of the match. The reason for defeat was a lack of concentration in the 1st and 91st minutes of the game. These two goals were seperated by a Christian Montano strike after a sustained period of pressure from the yellows. A penalty soon after was missed by Adam Chapman(only the 3rd of the season compared to the huge number given against us by referees who clearly have a grudge against Oxford for being a big club in a small league). United can take credit from an excellent performance. The evening was soured by a nasty altercation caused by Luke Guttridge who should have been sent off for retaliation on Liam Davis. This is the only time I have ever heard a football crowd chant the specific details of an incident towards the referee. Another League 2 ref out of his depth sadly.

Sixfields Stadium, Northampton, before the local derby between Northampton and Oxford.

item.title: Easter Camping: Day 7
item.description: Woolacombe, a seaside town with a lot of surfers
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Last full day! Had a long lie in necessitated by miserably cold wind and complete tiredness. I cooked a full English but this was complicated by wind blowing out the cooker flames and a lack of gas. It was cooked but it was eaten cold, which was disappointing. We spend the whole day at Woolacombe, it's bay being the best place for surfing in North Devon. As it was very cold I didn't fancy surfing, but took my wetsuit along anyway.

There is a rather pricey pitch and putt and within the first two holes I had lost my ball. There was a œ1 charge is it was not found which was a bit steep given the actual worth of the balls so I didn't pay it, though still managed to get a ball of the guy at the kiosk. After buying some wetsuit gloves I decided that if we were going to come all this way we might as well use the bodyboard. Sharing one between two would be alright in warm water, but standing around doing nothing when the waves weren't that good got a bit cold. Even so I managed to catch a few good waves and really enjoyed it, especially with the new gloves. Priority number 1 when getting home will be buying a 2nd bodyboard.

In the evening I had finally secured the mayorship of the local Wetherspoons so there was really only one option, Curry Club - delicious and nutritious (the last bit might be a lie). Our final stop was The Reform Inn. It's a reasonable walk from the main town centre but well worth it. There is a microbrewery on site and so a great selection of ales. The locals were really friendly and we played some of them at pool. The landlady offered to give us a tour of the brewery the following day but sadly we were leaving in the morning. If you are ever in Barnstaple you simply must go to the Reform Inn.


The Reform Inn provided top quality ales, good music, and friendly banter and pool.

item.title: Easter Camping: Day 6
item.description: Atlantic Village and the Big Sheep
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Cold and wet. Really cold. Just glad we haven't seen any of the snow down here or we'd be in for trouble. Today was earmarked as an indoor day from the start of the week due to the forecast. Just cereal for breakfast due to lack of enthusiasm for outdoor cooking.

We drove 2 miles south of Bideford along the A39 to two stops in close proximity. The first was Atlantic Village outlet centre. I bought Yorkshire pudding tins (how did we not already have these?), cake tin, Nike cycling gloves (decently sewn together by the good children of the Phillipines), two pairs of gloves from M&S (for œ5 and œ1), and a heap of chocolate from Cadbury's. This was a good outlet experience; not busy, not too many shops, not ridiculously expensive (why would I want expensive things if I'm cheap enough to go to an outlet store, eh? Yes I'm talking to you Bicester village)

The rest of the afternoon was at 'The Big Sheep' 1km back up the road. This is a family, sheep-themed attraction. In no particular order we did: beer tasting (on-site brewery called The Country Life), sheep racing, lazer shooting (loved sniping unsuspecting children from a hidden fort), swan shaped pedaloes called swanaloes (which I decided was a better name than pedoswans), pedal go-karts, sheep displays, lamb feeding, stroking tiny sheepdog puppies just a couple of weeks old, and kicking footballs at targets.


The Big Sheep had a wide range of activities, including learning about sheep and sheep racing.

A two for one with VoucherCloud brought it down to Â£6 each and coupled with Â£2 a pint we were onto a winner. Sadly I had wet and sandy socks due to the rule about no shoes on the jumping pillows and it being surrounded by a metre of sand and me leaving my shoes on the other side of the aforementioned sand. The giant vertical slide made up for this though. Every time I go on one of these it scares the hell out of me as I start to accelerate at 9.81m/s/s.

We tried booking for a restaurant near Woolecombe but it was booked up since they didn't have enough food. So we cycled away from Barnstaple for a change. On the way to Broughton, 2 miles down the road was the Tarka Inn but now the Broughton Inn. It's a Vintage Inn and was typically full but only had 2 waitresses. Disappointed when 2 pints of Tribute arrived with at least 1 cm of beer missing at the top (sent back for top up). Ordered the fish pie but it was sold out (though how exactly the next table managed to order one an hour later I don't know - bad waitress = small tip). Instead I had beef and ale pie with mash (delicious, especially with loads of horseradish). The cheeseboard for dessert was standard in quality but HUGE in quantity, even shared between two. I washed it down with a pint of Dutchman (9/10), a gorgeous orange-flavoured ale; light and perfect for dessert. Good food, would go to a Vintage Inn again.


The Braunton Inn is a former castle and current Vintage Inn pub.

item.title: Easter Camping: Day 5
item.description: Ilfracombe, Lymouth, and Lynton
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
A day of mixed weather. It started with a full English cooked on the stove (yummy). We drove to Ilfracombe along the new Barnstaple road and parked on a free street close to the centre. First we walked around the town. It's basically just one street of shops high up on the hill. Then down towards the cliffs we saw views of the sea and the theatre which is a lovely building seemingly designed to resemble a lime kiln (there are many of theses around North Devon as the soil is apparently quite acidic and the CaO is required for crops to grow well). To the side of this fantastic building is a commemorative mosaic to the world record triple jump set by Jonathan Edwards at a stunning 18.29m . I decided I would have my own attempt at this discipline. I paced back as far as I could. I waited for the toddlers to stop wasting my time. I ran. I took three jumps... 6.18m. Pathetic. I knew I was doing something wrong. A closer look and I saw that just alternating feet was not all there was to it. After realising the technique was much harder I decided the Edwards was a superhuman freak.


Local hero Jonathan Edwards's world record triple jump is commemorated in Ilfracombe. It's impossible to not have a go at the record yourself when you find it.

Then we sat in Runnymede gardens to have a snack. Having run out of snacks we hit Lidl to buy more. They do a very nice Mr. Choc range recreating such classics as Twix, Snickers, and Mars at only 25p.

The first sunbathe of the holiday was at the Tunnel Beaches. These tunnels were built by the Victorians as a way to create access to the beaches at the bottom of the cliffs. Otherwise this seaside town would have no beach! There are four consecutive tunnels in total. They lead to two beaches: originally a gentlemen's and a ladies beach (fortunately 'mixed bathing' is now permitted).


The entrance to the tunnel beaches is cold and dark, but the end are secluded sandy beaches, with plenty of rock pools and other areas to explore.

Also there is a tidal pool which is filled with fresh water twice a day. A brief period of Sun and a sheltered spot allowed a moment of tanning which I can only assume was admired by the general public. Walking around the rock pools was very cold and windy. Even colder was a quick swim in the tidal pool just before the waves came crashing over the pool edge. Glad for my wetsuit!

On one side are tall cliffs which needed to be tunnelled through, on the other is the Atlantic Ocean.

With the satnav still in epic fail mode I relied on google maps to guide me. Obviously a mistake. Most of the route was single track, in one point it was a 25% gradient, and it wiggled everywhere. I'm not even sure is some bits were a road. This took us the the Valley of the Rocks, but it decided to be the wettest and windiest in the last 6 months so we admired the view from the car. Another mile and we were parked in Lynton.

Lynton and Lynmouth shared a symbiotic relationship, sustained by an umbilical cord like cliff railway. Before this railway the two were basically screwed. In Lynmouth we learnt about the flood of 1952, bought some miniature baskets (5 for a Â£1), visited a free model railway exhibition, had a pint of Exmoor ale, and failed to buy a starfish as the miserable shopkeeper had shut at 4.30. Drove back to Barnstaple the sensible way.


The cliff railway between Lynmouth and Lynton. Much quicker than walking!

Tried to go to Zena's restaurant again. Still shut. So a pint in one Wetherspoon followed by a steak and beer in the other one rounded off the day. The chips in spoons are much improved. Incidentally whilst watching the Barca highlights in the news, did anyone else notice how hardly anyone behind the goal was celebrating Messi's 2nd? It was just tourists taking photographs. Sad.

item.title: Blackburn Rovers 0-2 Manchester United

Their first goal was a cross that was so rubbish it went in the net. 0-2. I thought Rovers played well but needed more up front towards the end.

item.title: Easter Camping: Day 4
item.description: The Tarka Trail and Bideford
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Barnstaple to Bideford. Separated by 9 miles, these two North Devon market towns once had a scenic railway running between them. Now they have a scenic cycle path: the Tarka Trail. This is an exceptionally well surfaced track running along the rout of the old railway.

We started by driving the bikes to near Barnstaple station finding the nearest free parking possible. The old line runs along where the car park is so it weaves in and out a little at first. The first stop was Fremington which has a cycle hire and a cafe. We just had a walk around here with a great view over the bay. After this we stopped a couple of times at the waypoints which matched an audio trail you can download of the trail's website.


The Tarka Trail follows the tidal rivers of Taw and Torridge. Dotted along the trail are sites of scientific and historical interest, such as the lime kilns long since abandoned.

The next village was Instow where I remember traffic needing to be stopped for the James May production and where the Hornby track was laid down within the gaps of the original rails.


The village of Instow still has a signal box and some of the original track. The beach has tall sand dunes with great views.

Then on to Bideford. Here there is the old station and signal box. Except they demolished all this so the track and signal box actually had to be restored in the 1990s! There are a couple of carriages at the old station, inside which are a cafe (scones and a coffee) and a museum.

We walked around town. I found a jumper in a charity shop I liked. We found a duck that thought he was a real person. Apparently he worked for the same charity shop. We had lunch and then we cycled back to Barnstaple.


Contrasting styles of bridge crossing the tidal rivers. Left is the A361 at Barnstaple. Right is Bideford Old Bridge which according to the local musuem has been rebuilt and widened many times.

I learnt from today that Chinese oven ready meals work perfectly fine in a pan on a stove, and cycling 28 miles in a day is very tiring.

item.title: Easter Camping: Day 3
item.description: Moving on to Barnstaple
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Felt like death this morning. Actual death. Packing up the tent was painful. Dealing with the still dodgy satnav still a nightmare. 2 hour drive to Barnstaple not the best cure. Stopped off in Yeovil on the way to eat some sandwiches, grab a coffee from Caff‚ Nero and look around town since I've not been before. Yeovil is basically two streets running parallel from the top of a hill to the bottom. I think I was expecting more from it. I did check out the M&S sale again and found some jeans I needed due to forgetting to pack any. They were Â£22 down from Â£45 which was decent but they rang up on the till at Â£12. Bargain:

On from Yeovil along the A361 North Devon link road to Barnstaple where we are staying for the next 5 nights at the Tarka Holiday Park. We moved from the pitch we were given as the turf had set rock hard, due to the dry spell we're having, into the shape of the tractor tyres which had massacred the surface. They've made a great deal of there pitches practically unusable.


We were the only residents in a tent. Too early in the season? Or did other people know something we didn't?

Cycled into Barnstaple along the Tarka trail (a disused railway which is now a superb cycleway through much of North Devon) for dinner in town. Walked around looking at the highlights: the Pannier market, the castle mound with drunk teenagers wishing me a happy Easter before shouting to her female friend 'I'm going for a piss. Don't follow me or I'll have sex with you'. Classy.


Barnstaple sits on the River Taw and has retained its charm and character.

Just the two Wetherspoons: The Panniers where I had a disappointing trio of thirds; then The Water Gate where I had a Scottish beer made from peated barley (7/10);. A couple of foursquare check ins with the ultimate goal of mayorship and 20% off the food bill before the end of the holiday. Dinner at Prezzo using a taste card where we shared a prosciutto and pear starter and a mixed bread board, followed by a calzone and beef ravioli. I nearly exploded but managed to fortunately keep my dignity. It is getting colder so the 3km cycle back was a bit on the nippy side. Definitely time for an early night. Shame about the lack of April Fool's Day opportunities. Fortunately Newcastle provided one by beating Liverpool. The scousers' season gets funnier and funnier!

item.title: Easter Camping: Day 2
item.description: Salisbury and the day of the marriage of Lucy & David
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
I do not like being awoken by church bells at 7am. Just as a 5am call to prayer from a mosque would be completely unacceptable, a bell ringing on the hour ever hour in the night is unnecessary. Grrr... We breakfasted at the campsite: toast with jam and a bacon sandwich and it was cheap.

We drove into Salisbury and found the closest free parking to the city centre, a good 15 mins walk away. We did the shops and I got a few items from the M&S sale. Then off to Wetherspoons for a Coffee Porter (8/10) and to change into wedding ware.

The ceremony was at the Salisbury registration office which is a lovely ornate building next to a beautiful park. The ceremony was done well except for when the registrar said 'the wedding of David and Caroline, sorry, Lucy'! The bride looked extremely happy during the vows. Photos and confetti were done in the park. There was plenty of time to kill before the reception so we went back to a charity shop to buy a wine rack, then got stuck in traffic on the way to Tesco. The satnav is playing up at the moment and made things difficult.


The register office is a beautiful building inside and out. Lucy and David signed the register after the vows were said.

Back to the campsite from whence we walked the 1.8 miles to Down Farm where the reception was. It was a right mission! We took emergency wine but it was unnecessary as there were 4 different legs of beer and cider from the local Sixpenny brewery (only 2 of which I tried) and a selection of Madeira and port. Plus finest Havana cigars! The speeches were excellent and were followed by a delicious hog roast. There were four different cakes so I had to try them all.


The hog roast was popular and there was plenty for seconds (and thirds, fourths...). The hat shaped cakes were stunning and as they were different flavours they all needed tasting.

A massive box of Lego was quite entertaining and I specialised in building random thing mostly which spun around. The coolest thing was a museum of all the things which have been found on the farm but I only had 2 mins as our lift was leaving. A massive preference to walking 30 mins in the dark. We took our wedding favours of a bay tree, marjoram, and a few other plants. Finishing at the campsite bar was a huge mistake...

item.title: Digital Gates and non-linear components
item.description: Week 3 of 6.002x
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
It was getting a bit sketchy as to whether I'd finish the week 3 assignments before the deadline of Friday. I worked for most of last night watching two lectures sequences, doing 87% of the homework and reading the lab task. It was a mammoth task although I got distracted towards the end by Domino's and red wine. The pressure was placed on me by myself due to a lack of doing anything earlier in the week and needing to pack for our Easter camping holiday which starts Friday night. Luckily I had an epithany this afternoon and worked out how to complete the lab in just a few minutes. I then completed the final two questions involving currents through diodes in 5-10 minutes by using node analysis.

The sequences this week showed how to build a digital gate using a MOSFET switch, which apparently have been in use for the last 40 years and current chips contain billions of these switches. Basically stick two in series and you've got a NAND gate, put two in parallel and you make a NOR gate. From these usefull building blocks you can use an inverter to make practically any logic gate you want it seems.

Also included was an introduction to non-linear elements and a range of tools you can use to solve analysis problems. I think my favourite is good ol' trial and error! I also think that the graphical method of looking at where two lines intersect has a certain beauty to it.

This week I have felt a lot more confident in solving the problems set and have a better understanding of the content. Next week I will have another deadline to help sharpen my focus, as we will not get back from Devon until Friday, then I'll be going to Northampton to watch Oxford that evening. Looks like I will have a busy Easter Saturday and Sunday, unless I can squeeze in two lecture videos tonight by packing the car as quickly as possible.

item.title: Plants in the pond
item.description: Stunningly hot day, spent buying plants and planting them
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
Today started by geting up early (8am in old money) to watch the Malaysian GP. A red flag situation after only 9 laps due to heavy rain caused a half hour delay so I gave up on the F1 and headed to Oxford to buy things for the garden. As promised we went to Maidenhead Aquatics to buy pond plants. We chose a selection of oxygenators, irises, a water lily, and a few grasses. The trip also gave us some inspiration for what to plant around the pond as they have a fantastic garden at the back. There are now 13 plants in the pond but it will take a month or two before they start to fill out space and add height. I have piled up some rocks in the corner to help access for frogs, etc.


Plants added around my pond in mid March 2012.

Behind the pond I planted a tree fern which has been in a pot for the last 6 months, and repotted other tree ferns and ferns by the stream at the back. Jo built some pretty sturdy net cloches which will stop the pigeons eating our stuff. The front is also starting to take shape - I finished the rest of the raised beds and started filling them in with soil. There are some bulbs and flowers in the bed, but there still loads to do out front.

item.title: Cheltenham
item.description: Day out in Cheltenham, watching the football and looking around town
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
A day out in Cheltenham: primarily watching Oxford. Jo and I arrived early in the morning and parked up in a free parking area only 10 minutes walk from the centre. We found a place for breakfast which did a Â£1.50 breakfast special. Cheap food seems to be a bit of a theme in Cheltenham as we found many completing places trying to undercut each other. The best was a 99p cafe where every item, whether a sandwich or a burger was 99p!


On the left, an ironic sign. On the right a shop name with two completely incongruous words: Cotswold and Kebab.

The M&S sale provided a great opportunity to spend my credit note and I got some nice tops. There's a decent range of shops including a lovely shopping centre with palms and a stream. The town centre is smart and pleasant to walk through. Oxford's shopping area has a lot to learn from this sort of place.

Before the football there was time to review both of the town's Wetherspoons. The first was the Bank House where I had a Norweigan bitter (6/10) brewed specials for 'Spoons. It was good but probably not the best choice for a hot day. The second was the Moon Under Water. Here I tried Fanny's Bramble (blackberry cider) 10/10 and Weston's twist (ginger still cider) 9/10, enjoyed in the most picturesque beer garden I've ever been in overlooking Sandford Park. Entertainment was a set of Football Managers Top Trumps (a quality set full of interesting stats). At 2.30 I set off for the Waddon Road.


Whaddon Road (or the Abbey Business Stadium for sponsorship reasons) was a sea of yellow and blue, with a strong away contingent.

Oxford fans filled just under a third of the stadium, well in advance of kick off.

The Abbey Business Stadium is a lot small than I thought it would be, it was packed an the attendance was only 4,300. Oxford brought a superb following and sang in good voice. Cheltenham dominated the opening stages coming close to scoring on a few occasions. The U's finally found their rhythmn and controlled possession before half time. Moments before the interval Oxford were denied a blatant penalty as Dean Morgan was tackled from behind in the box. The referee had a clear view but waved play-on. Shocking decision.

The second half required good concentration and defending as Cheltenham pressed, hoping to pick up their first win in 5 games. The game ended in a 0-0 draw, the result being a reasonable point for the yellows and a poor point for Cheltenham. Only 1 point in 15 has seen them fall from the automatic promotion places down to 6th. Oxford are unbeaten in 7, but are in danger of being caught by the impressive form of Crewe and Gillingham if they draw too many more games. Next up is the rearranged visit to Accrington on Tuesday night. Each game gets bigger and bigger.
