item.content:
It feel like the start of summer. In my south-faceing upstairs lab, with the blinds shut, all windows open and wearing a t-shirt, it was boiling. This inspired me to pay a visit to the garden centre, but I decided the tomato plants were still too small. I mean, why buy now when you can get the centre to do the donkey work and make them bigger first. They did have a great deal on a chimnea which now sits proudly in the fernery at the end of the garden. I spend some time weeding there this afternoon and discovered that it is particularly popular with midges given its shady, riverside location (more evidence of summer?) Perhaps this weekend will be the one for buying pond plants - pics to come if I do.

item.title: Circuit analysis and the digital abstraction
item.description: Week 2 of 6.002x
item.author: Tino Race
item.content: Week 2 of the MIT 6.002x course featured some new methods for analysing circuits, ones which make the whole business a great deal easier (if they are relevant to the problem). The other lecture sequence was about digital logic. A lot of the stuff on logic gates I already knew from general knowledge and even some electronics from Year 9 which I'd forgotten about. The digital logic is easy so far, but the circuit analysis can be tricky if it is not clear how to approach a problem. As is typical with university learning, you leave the lectures thinking 'I get it, this is easy', but once presented with a problem 'oh... erm???' There needs to be a clearer intermediatary step between the two. On the plus side, through perseverence I achieved another set of full marks on the week 2 lab and homework. I will need to get ahead for the next couple of weeks' lecture sequences before the Easter holidays.

I've put the Physics website on hold until I'm more clear on the timeline for this as I don't want to waste time doing something that would be replaced soon.

Both year groups are in the middle of coursework, we are very tight for time with teaching the course, and I am being observed very soon with one of these groups. item.title: Raising the Earth
item.description: Got bored - started digging
item.author: Tino Race
item.content: I got bored of waiting for the turf I dug up to rot down over the course of the next year, so I sorted it out and made a second large area usuable for growing vegetables. item.title: MITx 6.002x - Circuits and Electronics
item.description: I have started a new undergraduate course on MIT's prototype online learning system, MITx
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
This week saw the start of MIT's online learning initiative, called MITx. The prototype course is 6.002x Circuits and Electronics, and is an online version of their regular course 6.002. The course aims to bridge the gap between A-level Physics and understanding how electronic systems are built, stopping someway short of how computers are built. I have been very impressed with the course so far. It has been comprised of online video lectures by Professor Anant Agarwal, video tutorials, an interactive virtual circuit maker, and questions which self mark. There is also a textbook and the reading of this is optional. The relevant parts are online (a blessing given that its Â£55 on Amazon!) The online system is very easy to use, and if anything I think it is much easier to learn this way than by actually attending lectures.

I have completed week 1's lectures and tutorials well in advance of next Friday's deadline. The course is assessed as follows: 15% homework (computer marked questions), 15% labs (computer-marked virtual circuit building), 30% mid-term exam, 40% final exam. Solutions for the homeworks and labs are not available online but you are allowed to replace answers if you make mistakes. So far I got 100% on the homework and 100% on the lab (after a couple of minor corrections).

On completing the course I hope to be awarded an electronic MITx certificate, anything less than an A grade would be a disappointment. The course and certificate will be free on this course, but future ones will require a payment for the certificate. My main motivation for doing the course was to see how the style of tuition worked and so far I am really enjoying it. I imagine I will do other courses as long as the cost of the certificate is not crazy money!

Now to watch some football :)

item.title: Innovations in ICT
item.description: 3 days at the National Science Learning Centre
item.author: Tino Race
item.content:
This week I have been off school for 3 days on a CPD course entitled 'Innovations in ICT'. I went to the National Science Learning Centre, York, where I picked up some great ideas which I will be trialling between now and the summer holidays. Using a webcam as a cheap visualiser to show marked work, and to project demos and example work, looks like the simplest thing that could have a real benefit in the classroom. I have been given a free single-user licence copy of Word Wall. This is an activity maker which can easily make games such as crosswords, anagrams, wordsearches, etc in just a few seconds. I will start using this at KS3 and demonstrate this at some point in a meeting later this year. The final good idea which I will use is setting up a wiki for students to use. I see this working really well as a revision resource which children create and edit themselves. I will trial this with my sixth form classes.

The next step is to write an action plan for my reseach project and enter this for the Rolls Royce Science Prize. I will post the plan here when it is written as well as the findings of the project and any top tips I pick up. The follow up will be another 3 days at the NSLC in May. There is a wiki for this project too.

This is the first panorama I ever made using Occipital's 360 app for the iPhone. This is the greenhouse on the 3rd floor of the NSLC.

Having arrived in York early on the Monday, I visited York city centre. First I walked around the shops and saw York Castle Mound, with the adjacent Crown Court complementing it nicely. I also went past York Minster which I have been to before and have climbed to the top of to get a splendid view across the city.


York's buildings are an architectural joy.

Yorkminster towers above everything in the vicinity. It is a wonder how such a huge building got built such a long time ago.

Having arrived in York early on the Monday, I visited York city centre. First I went to the National Railway Museum at the back of York Station which is a very impressive place.


The National Railway Museum has an impressive collection of engines.
